did.unittitle: Hare-Willing Family Papers
did.abstract: This is a collection of letters, letterbooks, account books, scrapbooks, etc., concerning the families of Robert Hare and Thomas Willing. The letters and other documents include early family material, as well as documents written by numerous family relations, and some obviously only collected by them. The Willing family letters (1744-1901) are diverse, concerning family matters, business, society, comments on the Civil War, etc. There are numerous letters from Thomas Willing, many concerning his banking career, as President of the Bank of North America and later at the first Bank of the U.S. The Hare family letters (1724-1965) are more extensive and diverse, including much on travel in the U.S. and elsewhere. There is a letter from Robert Hare Jr. concerning steam engines, and letters from Horace Binney Hare concerning his education at Harvard, 1860, his trip to San Francisco and the west, 1862, and numerous letters written while a soldier in the Civil War. There are many letters from Horace Binney (1780-1875, DAB) to his daughter Esther, who was married to John Innes Clark Hare (1816-1905, DAB), concerning family travel and court cases. There are also letters from outside the family, such as those from Dorothea L. Dix. The bound volumes include, among others: Robert Hare letterbooks (1824-1825, 1841-1857), estate records, and laboratory expense accounts (1818-1860); G. H. Hare's journal or log of cruises aboard the U.S. United States (1841) and U.S. Flint (1845); Horace Binney Hare's 1862 journal of his trip to San Francisco. There are account books and accounts (1754-1795) kept by Thomas Willing; accounts of the controversy over the estate of John Innes Clark; and records of the First Colored Wesley Methodist Church of Philadelphia (receipt book, 1820-1848; minute book, 1827-1844). There are also Philadelphia court records, and minutes of the Common Council of the city, 1832.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Presented by Mrs. Henry Meigs and Truxtun Hare, Jr., and accessioned, 04/28/1981 (1981 1624ms).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Robert Hare, an English immigrant in 1773, was a prominent businessman and served in the Pennsylvania legislature and as a trustee of the University of Pennsylvania. He married Margaret Willing, sister of Thomas Willing, who was a banker and official and legislator in Pennsylvania. Their son, Robert, was a chemist and inventor and taught at the University of Pennsylvania. In the third generation, John Innes Clark Hare was a distinguished Philadelphia judge. His son, Dr. Horace Binney Hare was an instructor of Chemistry and professor of Hygiene. Married to Emily Power Beale in 1868, they had five children, Robert Hare, Charles Willing Hare, Esther Binney Hare, Horace Binney Hare, married to Ellen Mary Cassatt, and Thomas Truxtun Hare, a track and field Olympic medal winner in 1900, 1904.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Materials previously noted with the call number Ms. Coll. 6 are now contained within this collection.

odd.head: African American History Note
odd.p: Of particular interest to students of African American history are records of the First Colored Wesley Methodist Church of Philadelphia (receipt book, 1820-1848; minute book, 1827-1844).

odd.head: Early American History Note
odd.p: This is a large and wide ranging collection on materials. The collection contains over 1300 individual items along with 53 bound volumes, which range from letter books to records of the First Colored Wesley Methodist Church. Letters to and from the various members of the extended Hare-Willing family compose the bulk of the loose correspondence.

The Willing Family papers consist of over 500 items ranging from 1744 to 1863, with the bulk from the nineteenth century. The early papers relate primarily to the business career of Thomas Willing, former partner of Robert Morris and President of the First Bank of the United States. The family was later involved in establishing the Baring Company. The letters from the 1820s onward are an assortment of personal and professional correspondence of Thomas Willing’s son, Thomas Mayne, and grandchildren, mostly between Charles Willing and his sister Elizabeth Sterling, that touch on matters political, social, cultural, and economic. Topics of discussion include poetry, literature, medical treatments, and social customs and mores, including things such as dueling and courtship. Because of their financial situation, the letters discuss important economic events, such as the Panic of 1825, which resulted in the Stirling family’s business closing. Politics is occasionally but not often discussed. Some of the records relate to the estate they received from their parents.

Numerous letters detail the family’s history, including discussions of education, travel, finance, and relationships within the family. Some of the family news is deeply personal, including discussions of medical and financial problems, miscarriage, and unhappiness with others in the family. Notably, there is a series of letters written by Charles Willing in the 1820s and 1830s from European cities, such as Milan, Rome, and Paris.

The Hare Family correspondence is equally focused on the nineteenth century. The Hare family correspondence includes letters from Robert Hare Jr., the leading chemist of his day, and Horace Binney, a leading legal thinker of his day whose daughter married into the Hare family. The nature of the Hare correspondence is very similar to the Willing correspondence, although there is more correspondence that is political in nature. Discussions include education, family matters, personal affairs, and current events. Some of the letters from the Civil War era capture the mobilization of the city.

Of particular note, the Binney correspondence discusses his involvement in the legal case regarding the Stephen Girard Estate. Girard’s heirs contested portions of his will that gave portions of his estate to charity. Binney argued successfully against the heirs’ claims, who were themselves represented by Daniel Webster, in the Supreme Court. The Court’s decision established important case law for protecting charities. The collection includes a letter Binney wrote to his wife while sitting in the Supreme Court amidst arguments. Also of some interest may be a diary kept by Charles Hare, nephew of Robert Hare, that details his escape as a British prisoner of war from the French jail at Verdun in 1809; the diary is typescript and the originals are not part of the collection.

The major difference between the Hare and the Willing portions of the collection – aside from the letter writers - is the chronological focus. The Hare collection is particularly focused in the 1840s onward. The Willing correspondence is strongest in the 1820s-1840s.

The Hare-Willing Collection also includes over 50 bound volumes that range from the colonial era to the Civil War era. The volumes are diverse and include account books, receipt books, letter books, travel journals, and minute books from Philadelphia organizations. A chronological list of the books with brief descriptions follows:

1. Accounts of Thomas Willing (1754-1760) and Estate of Capt Sam Appowen, 1767-1776 - A ledger book that records the financial transactions of Thomas Willing during his years a prominent Philadelphia merchant, including his time as partner of Robert Morris. The records of the estate of Sam Appowen are also detailed, for which Willing apparently served as executor.

2. Accounts of Thomas Willing, Thomas Willing Francis and/or the firm of Willing and Francis, 1789 – 1795 - Ledger book contains a wide array of transactions conducted, which appear to be commercial in nature and include supporting “adventures” to India, Martinique and other places abroad, which provides insight into the range of commercial activity in the early republic and the goods being brought into and sold.
3. Docket of the Court of Common Pleas of Philadelphia County – 1793-1812 -Volume lists plaintiffs and defendants with court actions

B. The Account Book of Thomas Willing, 1754-1786 - The book details Willing’s business transactions from the colonial era to the early republic, with most records coming from the post-Revolution era. Included are bank notes and other receipts, along with detailed business transactions with individuals and other firms. Records of various merchant ships are also included.

A. Estate book and Receipt book of Willing and Morris and records of the estate of Clement Plumstead, 1745-1765 - Clement Plumstead was a member of one of Philadelphia’s most prominent families. A slender volume records the management of his estate for the year 1745. A second, larger ledger book in this portion of the collection documents the receipts of Willing and Morris from 1760 to 1765.
8. Records of Wharf, 1802 - A collection of boats that came into a wharf, likely one owned by Willing, for the months of October 1802 – February 1803.

5. Accounts of Philip Wilson, 1800-1811 - Financial transcaction of Philip Wilson, captain based out of Philadelphia. Included in the front of the book are legal records from 1805 that chronicle an ill-fated voyage Wilson took from France to the U.S. aboard the Mars. He encountered a storm and brought the ship into Ireland, where he had to repair the ship and give a number of depositions for insurance reasons.

9. Thomas Willing’s Account with the Bank of the U.S., property of Charles Willing Hare, and Letters and Accounts of Thomas Mayne Willing regarding the Bingham Estate, 1810-1822 - This ledger has three types of documents. The first is a brief account of the will and estate of Charles Willing Hare. The second details Thomas Mayne Willing’s accounts and stocks held in the First Bank of the United States, an institution for which he eventually served as president. These accounts may also be related to the Hare estate. The final set are the records of the Bingham Estate, and Thomas Willing’s execution of it, which include a series of letters from the 1820s. These letters are sometimes personal and discuss a range of topics, such as attempts to have a family member receive a commission in the Navy
11. Robert Hare Accounts, 1819 and 1828 – 1846 - This large ledger books stores the daily purchases and financial transactions of Robert Hare, the noted American chemist.

13.Robet Hare – Extracts – 1823 - This appears to be a commonplace book of Robert Hare. The large folio volume contains moves through an alphabetical list of words with definitions, ideas, and other matter. It is not clear if Hare copied the content or wrote it himself, although it appears at a minimum that some of the entries are Hare’s own original thoughts.
5a – E.C. Binney’s Notebook on Orinthology - This notebook contains a list of bird species and their characteristics.

1a – Abby Willing’s Daybook – 1784-1789 This journal records the daily purchases of the Willing household, lending insight into the consumption patters and tastes of one of the more prominent Philadelphia families.
9a – Orphan’s Court Records for Bryan Wilkinson Estate, 1843 - A printed legal document relating to an audit of the Wilkinson estate.
21 – Dr. Charles Willing – Accounts, 1845-1847 - List of financial dealings of Willing that include his private accounts as well as those he managed for various estates.

19 – Clark Hare – Court cases and writings, 1842-1850 - Contains a list of court cases with defendants, plaintiffs, and the court’s action. The back contains some writings on a variety of topics, presumably by Clark Hare as well.
18 – Robert and Clark Hare Letter book, 1842-1857 - A letter book of primarily Clark Hare on a range of matters. There are some letters from Robert Hare as well.

14 – Robert Hare – Partial letter book 1824-1825 - The fragmentary letter book is a very fragile copy of Hare’s outgoing letters for primarily 1825. The letter book appears to be carbon copies, a relatively early use of this technology.

10 – Letter book regarding the Estate of John Innes Clark, 1811-1830 - The letter book contains correspondence as it relates to settling the estate of John Innes Clark, a Rhode Island based merchant. The correspondents include Robert Hare, who marries Clark’s daughter.
3a – Horace Binney Hare’s book of formula - 1861 - A collection of chemical and mathematical processes, formulas, and equations.
6 – P[hilip] Wilson Account Book - Ledger Book A of Philip Wilson for 1800-1811, recording a variety of financial transactions.
7 – Account Book, 1801-1806 - An account book from 1801-1806 of unknown ownership.

6a – Notes and Observations of England and Scotland, 1836-1837 -This is a fascinating journal, perhaps written by Robert Hare. The observations often compare society to America’s. The author, for instance, points out how political patronage in America is practiced but obscured from view, while in England it is a point of pride. Other entries involve witnessing a coal workers strike, copious notes on newspaper editorials and reports, and other cultural observations, such as the drinking culture of England.
Unnumbered – Esther Hare Account Book 1884
Unnumbered – 1830 Annals of Philadelphia by John Watson
Misc 3 – Emily Hare, Address and Account book, 1880-1882
16 – John Binney Copy book, 1859 and John I.C. Hare, 1860
17a – The Theological Commonplace book with letters to Blanche from Mary Ellen written in the blank pages, 1859-1860
70a – Legal notes on Law – mid to late 19th century
67a – Charles Willing Hare, Minutes from Blackstone’s Commentaries on Laws of England
20 – Robert Hare, Jr., Letter book, 1844-1845 - This letter book contains series of letters Hare wrote that primarily involve his business affairs.
15 – Robert Hare Jr., Letter Book, 1833-1844 - The letters in this book relate primarily to legal matters and affairs, most of which Hare is involved in one way or another.

4 – Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas and Supreme Court of Eastern Pennsylvania, 1795-1811 - This large volume contains the records of both the Philadelphia Court of Common Pleas and the Supreme Court of Eastern Pa. The records contain the names of those on trial, and occasionally details of the trial. The first half chronicles the court of Common Pleas from 1795-1811 and usually contains the docket number and names of those on trial. The records of the Supreme Court are shorter in chronology, covering the years 1803-1809.

69a – Robert Hare Chemistry Notes - Robert Hare was a leading chemist in the nineteenth century and this notebook may be of interest to historians of science. The book contains a statement written by Hare about chemistry and the job of a chemist. It is likely that this notebook served as the basis for some of Hare’s lectures.
18a – Horace Binney Hare Account book, 1860-1866 - List of purchases, marked “Private”

19a – Horace Binney Hare – Journal to San Francisco, 1862 - Sixty four page journal of Hare’s trip to San Francisco, notable for his detailed observations on San Francisco life and his “adventures” in the city.

2b – Robert Hare, Sr., Account book, 1763 - This volume is the account book of Robert Hare, Sr., Philadelphia brewer. The account book, however, is from his time in London before he traveled to Pennsylvania to establish himself. Hare appears to have been a merchant or involved in trade on some level, as many of the entries relate to ships, insurance, and exchange of consumer goods.
Unnumbered – Estate documents - A statement regarding the confusion over the estate of John Inees Clark, most likely by Robert Hare

Unnumbered – Diagrams and Plans of the Principal Battles by James Wilkinson, 1816 - This printed book contains detailed maps of various battles in American history from the Revolution to War of 1812 that Wilkinson participated in.
12 – First Colored Wesley Methodist Church, Receipt Book, 1820-1848 - Record of purchases and other financial transactions.

Misc 2 – Minute Book of First Colored Wesley Methodist Church, Minutes, 1827-1841 - The Minute Book contains a complete record of the Board of Trustee’s of the church. The actions and debates may be a rich resource for a historian of the era studying African American history.

Misc 1 – General Atlas for Carey’s Edition of Guthrie’s Geography - Rare atlas printed in Philadelphia in 1795 that includes various maps, including an atlas of lands charted by Cook and of each U.S. state.
6b – Clark Hare, Legal Notes, 1851 - Various notes, including notes of cases Hare apparently tried.
5b – Records of executor of Robert Hare’s Estate, 1846-1848 - A very brief account of the estate.
4b – Minutes of the Common Council, 1832 - Robert Hare served as clerk for the council and this volume records much of their activity.

3b – Robert Hare Account Book of Lab Expenses, 1818-1826 - This volume chronicles the purchases that Robert Hare, one of the leading chemists of his day, made for his lab and its experiments, providing insight on his equipment and the operation of his lab.

2b – Robert Hare’s Material Relating to Estate of John Innes Clark, 1813-1824 - This volume is a detailed accounting of the estates accounting, including reports on property that John Innes Clark held, including various land holdings in western territories.
15a – Diary/Commonplace, possibly of Mrs. Tillinghast, Rebecca Willing’s mother - Miscellaneous daily notes and entries
12a – The Republican Court, Rufus Griswold
11a – Robert Hare Estate, Accounts 1847-1861 - A very brief accounting of the transactions of the Robert Hare Estate
10a – Robert Hare’s Expenditures and Receipts, 1845-1858 - While this includes regular transactions of Hare, it also contains an accounting of his examination of an oyster shell and a hand drawn map.
8a – Robert Hare Letter Book 1841-1857 - A collection of letters from Robert Hare.
7a – G.H. Hare’s Journal aboard the United States (1841) and the schooner Flirt (1845) - Daily log of voyages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business correspondence of Thomas Willing regarding stocks, land purchases, and the Bank of North America from 1744-1822. Letters of Charles Willing to his father and from his relatives in Scotland, 1822-1883, regarding receipt of remittances and family news.

did.unittitle: Nancy Willing to C. Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Arrived in Liverpool. She and Emma suffered some sea-sickness. Leaving today for Manchester. Favourable voyage.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of Emma, Nancy, Tom and Charles. Few factory-business seems well. To show sisters relatives and this part of world. Nancy giving Jane dancing lessons. Urging to study medicine, maybe in England.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: James' marriage. Placed Nancy and Emma at a school in Chelsea.

did.unittitle: Caroline to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discussion on agreeable and disagreeable persons when traveling. Sees Charles Mifflin as a "vampire" using his bleeding skull. Much gaiety. Morris studying law.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Moved from Bow Churchyard. Explanation of health. Nancy and Emma's schooling and characters. Heard Crammonde plan to return to England and against it. Requests copy of General Harrison's picture.

did.unittitle: C. Bollmann to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Encouragement in stay at Cambridge. Accounts of parties and marriages. A short postscript.

did.unittitle: Emma Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pleasant voyage but was seasick. Elizabeth Stirling: Weak from cold-expects confinement. John went to America with Captain Wormley. Under consideration to build addition to business which would make it largest in Lanceshire. Hopes Crammonds will not come to England. Ann Willing: At school in England, learning music, dancing, writing, and geography.

did.unittitle: Betsey to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Went to Quaker tea party and disappointed in its not being a stiff ceremonious one. Hasn't read novel mentioned.

did.unittitle: C. Bollmann to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Had the "ague". Missed Picknick breakfast, but hope to attend Strawberry Party. Three weddings. Wants Mr. Bancroft's book. Did not like Lord Byron's poem "Deformed Transformed".

did.unittitle: H. Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: General Harrison's picture to be sent to Mrs. Stirling. Something about a lot?

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Social.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Birth of son, Thomas Mayne. May 30, 1824. Cold and remedies - bleeding cupping, leeching and blistering. Nancy and Emma's schooling and characters. Questionable conduct of Mrs. H. Baring. Awkward for us to decide whether you should visit Tom Bingham. Tombstone for parents.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ill health of Elizabeth. Birth of son, Thomas Mayne. Discusses proposed trip to Canada. Would be sorry to see Crammonds leave United States. Will send stockings to Aunt Powel. News of Emma and Nancy.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apology for preventing visit to Montreal. News of children. Shameful conduct of Mrs. H. Baring. Factory well.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Annoyed at not receiving children's funds. Saw Matthews in "Jonathan". News of baby, Nancy and Emma.

did.unittitle: Francis Baring to R. Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Confidential) Relative to papers of Vincent Nolte Company, New Orleans.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ill with jaundice and deranged bilious system. Cheltenham, best water in England for bilious complaints. News of Emma, Mayne, Andrew, Jane and Mrs. H. Baring. Concern (textile factory) doing well. Ask about remittances. Pleased you and Uncle Richard to be trustees of Mother's will.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Gifts to Jane and sisters received. "Change of air" at Henly Park good. Thought foxhunt one of prettiest sights ever seen. News of the children and Nancy and Emma. Difficulties between Mr. and Mrs. H. Baring. Saw Sir Walter Scott's son - comments on him and father. Factory doing well.

did.unittitle: Caroline (cousin) to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mary Willing's dance. Anxious to see Mr. Everett's oration on the anniversary of the landing of Pilgrims. Analysis of Professor's oration. Comments on Charles Mifflin and T. Willing.

did.unittitle: Emma Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thank you for present. Going to spend holidays with sister.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Children have "hooping cough." Nancy improving in character and Emma doing well. Economizing to get business going which is doing very well. Against Crammonds return to Jersey.

did.unittitle: Caroline Bollmann to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Henrick's letter in German. Comments on Miss Binney's dance, marriages, parties, Uncle Nixon, Harrisburg legislature and Prior's Book.

did.unittitle: Charles Mifflin to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Quotations and thoughts.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Death of Admiral's wife. Children had "hooping cough". News of Emma and Ann and their improvements. Heard Catalini (singer). Extraordinary advance in cotton and how may affect factory.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Emma had "hooping cough". Going home for holidays and to spend part of it at Isle of Wight.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wants to hear on Elizabeth Springs death. Read Tremaine. News of Nancy and Emma. Propose taking house at Isle of Wight. Factory prospering.

did.unittitle: C. Bollmann to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of visit to Mrs. Commodore Stewart.

did.unittitle: Henry Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Commencement at Cambridge. Entering into medicine. Advice on whether or not to make trip to Canada. Expense account and advise to economize.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Family news.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Staying at Henley Park. Hottest weather in 30 years brought on severe bilious attack. News of children. Dines with Mrs. Col. Phips, daughter of Mrs. Arnold (the traitor's wife). News of Ann and Emma.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling, Ann Willing to Chas. _____, Mrs. Stirling

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosed Nancy's letter.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of Nancy and Emma and their schooling. General news.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Scarletina and chickenpox. Refers to deed of trust. Report on nacy and Emma. Going to see Duke of Windsor lie in state and British Museum. Nancy now goes by name Ann.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Panic among bankers due to mercantile business. Sir Walter Stirling.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business stoppage (details)

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explanation of business failing and desirability of children's remaining to study at least 2 years longer. (Ann and Emma)

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Failure of business.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of Tom and Jane. Expect you to send "Virgil" to Tom.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business arrangements. Children. Relatives in India. Marriage of Mrs. H. Baring to Marques de Blaisel.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Here for "change of air". Admiral likes the children. Elections. Captain sailed to Cape of Good Hope and India. Mrs. Baring has made a good match.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Weather, farmers and business in country. Personal business probably bankrupt. Ann and Emma.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business bankrupt. Deaths mentioned of Adams and Jefferson.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Birth of daughter to Elizabeth. Comments on Mrs. Bingham, Canada and Mr. Forsyth. Meeting in regards to estate.

did.unittitle: J.S. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Birth of daughter. Sir Walter wants from America a small quantity of seed of vegetable called "Lamb's Quarter's".

did.unittitle: H. R_____ ? to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Exhausted serving American friends. Discussed Tom, music and friends.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Birth of daughter, Mary. Certificate for business. Will decide future plans. Possibility of going to Chile. Andrew playing cricket at school.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John and Walter's business. Gave up idea of going to South America. Changes in Nancy and Emma since coming to England. News and health of children.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expect business certificate. News of Nancy and Emma. Jane, Anna and Lizzy had scarletina. To visit Admiral at Woburn.

did.unittitle: Emma Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At home for Christmas holidays. Tom to be christened and Nancy to be godmother.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Talks of music, drawing and books at present reading "Rollin's Ancient History". Spent Easter with Mr. Stirling's sister. To be Godmother to Tom.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on becoming of age. News of Nancy and Emma. Refers to fire on Penn St. Feels price for woodlands low. Business - bankruptcy.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Refers to Elizabeth's Trust deed. Expects to see Tom Francis in Liverpool.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Jaundice. Disappointed in amount received this year from Mama's estate - last year Mr. Binney sent more. Took advantage of Mr. Baring to ask him for employment for her husband.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: "Change of air" for jaundice. Ann and Emma joined during Easter holidays. Ann confirmed. Charles Stirling and Admiral's daughter. Charlotte married. Certificates processed (reference to Mr. Stirling's business with brothers). Topsy-turvey politics.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ann and Emma - Windsor Castle. John Stirling's negotiations with brothers. John looking for employment. Francis Baring.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Objection to plan to send sisters to France (Ann and Emma) to school. "Painful" to do so, but spoke of characters of Ann and Emma.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Displeasure over prospect of going to France for education. Enjoyed vacation with Admiral Stirling at Woburn.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explanation of objections to schooling Ann and Emma in Paris. Francis Baring - business (emplyment). Moving to St. Andrews, Scotland.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Expects to see him in April. Sister in Scotland. Family news and friends.

did.unittitle: C. Bollmann to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About little box (valuable) to be delivered to Mr. Taxier or his daughter Madame Thieron in Paris.

did.unittitle: C. Bollmann to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: April 12, News of Betsey. Talk of Paris. B.B. to Charles Willing, April 9, Discusses travels, music, books, and friends.

did.unittitle: Henry Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: What to do with interest on legacies? Giving advantages of America over New Holland for W. Stirling.

did.unittitle: Charles Blight to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Distribution legacy money. Investment for William Bingham. Mr. Baring - Pennsylvania lands.

did.unittitle: Henry Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittances sent. Wine bottled as directed.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of payment of bill.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Credit to your account.

did.unittitle: J.M. Binguet to ______
Caroline to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Nancy's engagement to Mr. Blight. James Marloe's engagement to Sally Fisher. Two duels intended to take place (details of each). Social - commenting on pleasures of discussion. Details of their tour last summer.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Credit to account from H. Hollingsworth.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on bequest from "Old Lady's will". News of Ann, William, Agnes, Emma and James at the Colony.

did.unittitle: Henry Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittance sent. Opinions on Union Canal Loan and stock. Duel between William Miller and Lt. Hunter. Mr. Walsh inquires how long can have house on 3rd St.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friend Miller killed in a duel. A most "shabby" fellow for not getting "stays".

did.unittitle: Caroline and Betsy Bollmann to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of family and friends in Philadelphia. Thank you for volume of music.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Credit to account.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advising of error (letter of 2nd void).

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Curious about his freindship with royalty. Account of William's birth (15 lbs.). Mentioned Sir John and Lady Nasmyth, Lady Erskin, and about Ann's many proposals.

did.unittitle: Richard Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Scolding on remaining in Paris too long. Will not maintain Tom (an idler) any longer. Record of account.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Pertaining to account.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Credit to account from Hollingsworth, Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to account.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of children and remodeling of house. Agitation in country about reform. Andrew to go into Navy.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Discussion on whether Ann and Emma return to America or remain in Scotland.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Made up mind not to return to America. Fearful of the cholera.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request to get "stays" and 1 dozen fine cambric handkerchiefs.

did.unittitle: Ann Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plea to allow her to judge her suitor, Captain Dalgleish, instead of allowing Mr. Stirling's refusal of proposal.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explaining his objections to Ann's suitor and asking opinion.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All "now off" between Ann and Captain Dalgleish. Now interested in Mr. Murray (full account of him).

did.unittitle: H. Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittance to Baring Brothers for account. Mr. Binney, executor of Mother's estate paid into account. Discusses rents, investments, lands, etc.

did.unittitle: Allyn Otis, J. Francis Fisher to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Urging to come to Paris. News of Madame de Blaisel and Francis Baring. Political news of America. News of friends and family.

did.unittitle: Maria M. duBlaisel to Monsieur Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Invitation to call.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers & Co. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account balance (debit).

did.unittitle: A.O. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plan to meet in London and return together to America. How they spent their time.

did.unittitle: Walter Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Forwarded black trunk. Regret at not seeing him because of change of plans. Description of Sir Thomas Beever Nart who has a letter of introduction.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers to C. Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Copy of letter to Baring Brothers. Draft negotiations.

did.unittitle: A.O. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cholera in the south of England. Changes of plans in sailing to America because of cholera.

did.unittitle: Welles & Co. to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Feel that mistakes in account must be with Baring Brothers & Co.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Elizabeth ill with what is called a "weed" meaning a cold. Business in Edinburgh. News of Mrs. Murray (Ann) and Mrs. Gray. Jane and Lizzy visited Lintrose (Ann Murray). Cholera.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to C. Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Elizabeth's illness. Discusses reform bill. Feels that cholera is on the decline. Received news of safe arrival in Philadelphia.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. MacSparren's death and legacy. Cholera at London and Dundee. News of the Murrays, Jane, Ann and Miss Wilson. Violent reformers - Dr. Gillespie and Kirby D.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers to C. Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Financial.

did.unittitle: Allyne Otis to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Finds America "stale, flat and intolerable". Comments on Reform Bill. Friendly and amusing.

did.unittitle: J. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: MacSparren's will. Asks advise as to how to pay back what he owes. News of Fisher. Reform Bill passed.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cholera epidemic in the Kingdom and has now reached Philadelphia. Visit from Ann (Emma returned home with Ann). Andrew unable to get in Navy. Request that Hollingsworth make over Ann's property to her husband, Murray. Mentions Fisher and death of Sir Walter.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to C. Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Cholera abated. Going to "Lintrose". News of Ann, Elizabeth, Willie, and Andrew. The Wilsons ill. Mr. Baird and Colonel Glass dead. Miss Binney dying, also her father. Mrs. Young died and her husband taken to drink. Elections.

did.unittitle: T.W. Francis to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Twelve pair boots ordered and expenses on same. Cooper writings may injure American cause with France. Speaks of friends and relatives.

did.unittitle: Emma Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News of the children, Miss Binney's death and about her father.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Going to England. Captain James to return to Swan River Colony. Andrew's future - Manchester of Swan River. News of family and friends.

did.unittitle: J.P. Corbin to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Asking to remit for subscription, in reimbursement of duty paid on rifle.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Andrew going to Colony (Swan River) with Sir James. General news.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Renunciation of Trusteeship. July 12, Proposal on how to pay the loss of father's estate.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explanation of intention to pay back money to father's estate.

did.unittitle: Ann Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thank you for gun for Murgo. Are in St. Andrews for sea bathing for health. Andrew to sail with Uncle Sir James Stirling for Swan River. Captain Stirling (Sir James) honored by friends of settlers. Would like to have you come live in this country.

did.unittitle: Ann Murray to Charles Wilson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returned from visit to Edinburgh (death of Mrs. Gray). Andrew going to Swan River with Sir James. Sally Crammond's death. Haven't received remittance. Murray pleased with rifle.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Andrew to go to Western Australia to try his fortune. According to plan has paid on account.

did.unittitle: Baring Brothers to Charles Wilson

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Debit and credit in account.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Halsey's death. Vessel unable to sail due to long continuance of westerly winds. Ann to go to continent. Request for account of property, how it is doing and opinion of how Hollingsworth manages.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mr. Brown died. Visit to the Highlands (Loch Lomond). Jane to make her debut at ball. Walter's friend, Mrs. Jones dead. Andrew and Sir James at Cape.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: News about Emma, Anna, Murray and Ann. Scotland politics and unrest. Emma's money and property. Two rifles requested.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to paper of trustee for Emma. Papers for Emma and Elizabeth executed and forwarded. Forwarded parcel and draft to Ann at Florence. Anxious to receive rifles. Visits to family with Emma and Jane. Tom's injuries in fall over cliff. Elizabeth's New York lands.

did.unittitle: Henry Hollingsworth to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statement of funds. Request to know Emma's share of last years income.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ann had miscarriage. Suspicion the Murray family are "in the dark" as to Ann's means. Elizabeth near confinement. Haven't heard from Andrew at Colony. Tom at school.

did.unittitle: Emma Willing to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Return Deed of Trust with request advance be made if necessary. Heard Ann's to winter in Florence. Colony thriving very well.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Apology for not transacting business, but couldn't because of cholera in town. Palaces they are visiting. Papers signed.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Birth of son, John. News of Emma and Ann. Andrew says Colony progressing favourably.

did.unittitle: Emma Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Aunt's letter enclosed to be dispatched. Request acceptance of share of American wine.

did.unittitle: Richard Willing to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Statement of accounts of Charles Willing, Emma Willing, and Murgo Murray. Describe financial status in country.

did.unittitle: Richard Willing to Elizabeth Stirling

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to forms to be signed in regard to father's estate.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Near disaster in coach. Dolly moved to Duradin for health. Expect winter in Boulogne. Elections. Death of Marquis of Bath.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Stirlings were looking for house in this part of country. Lizzy ill. Murgo deer hunting with Sir John MacKenzie. Ordering a rifle for Murgo. Comments on the Queen. Murgo fond of fishing.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Anxious about property in America. Dorothea's cough - necessary to move to mild climate at Stirling. General news of family and friends.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Tom settled in Manchester. Preparations for Anna's marriage to Henry Maitland. Dorothea's illness.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Comments on Canada, the burning of the steamboat Carolina, relations between America and England, and English politics. Anna to marry Henry Maitland. Building a greenhouse and bathroom.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Henry and Anna's wedding. Dorothea's illness.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledged remittance. Spent a week in Edinburgh with Emma who has water in the abdomen. James Maitland wrote Emma is "gaining ground". Saw Anna in Edinburgh. Fears press is trying to embroil England and United States in war. Comments on Governor Durham. Damage to roses during winter. News of the Stirlings and Jane.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stiring to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Emma's condition. Anna's happiness. Expect to winter in Edinburgh for Dorothea's health. Snow at St. Andrews, fourteen feet deep. (last winter)

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing
John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Emma's death. Disappointment in will. Elizabeth Stirling: Regard to will.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Emma's death and concern over will. E.S.: Concern over will.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Disappointment in James Maitland and Emma's will. Copy of John's letter to James on same.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: About secrecy of Emma's will.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Regret over Emma's will. Received her thimble and piece of hair. Dorothea's illness. Elizabeth unwell. News of Henry Maitland, Tom and Murray. John Hays taking a house in Edinburgh.

did.unittitle: Ann Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipt for remittance. Fears Lizzie is laying on deathbed, and Dolly very ill. Doubtful of steamships. Thank you for executing commission (must be rifle).

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lizzy's illness and death.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lizzy's illness and death.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Death of Lizzie from fever allied to typhus. The whole Stirling family contracted it, even sister who will be confined the end of the month. Comments on Canadian Rebellion, Lord Durham, India and "Sam Slick". To have portrait painted by Mr. McInnis.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Baby girl born December 15, Emma Elizabeth Maitland Stirling. Little Elizabeth died. Agnes dying of typhus fever. Jane and Willie also ill. Dorothea improved.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Agnes died (typhus fever). Family's health.

did.unittitle: Francis Fisher to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ed off to New York station, and to be in Philadelphia. Request to introduce him Madame Ersland, Mrs. Tom Willing and Cousin Ellen. Request to find a good "ladies horse". General social.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Inquiry as to Fisher's wedding. Health of jane and Dolly. Fever severe in Edinburgh - Stagnant water around town suspected. Baby christened Emma Maitland. Expecting Andrew any day (gone 6 years). News of Tom, Ann, Walter Stirling and Henry and Anna Maitland. Hope there is no war between England and America.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledged remittance. Advising to sell stores and put money into United States Bank. Stirlings returning to St. Andrews and Andrew arriving. Comments on the Queen and ministry. Dolly's recovery - can now walk and eat. Anticipating visit to America (land of birth).

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to papers of trustees. Dolly much better. Expecting Andrew from Colony. News of Jane. Willie, Hanry and Anna.

did.unittitle: M. to William Black

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On proposals, marriages and friends. (a drawing in letter).

did.unittitle: Mr. Church to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business connected with lands.

did.unittitle: Henry Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of lots owned by Mrs. Murray and late Mrs. maitland advertised to be sold for taxes due.

did.unittitle: Richard Willing to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on engagement. Request to be in Philadelphia in July to receive audits and transfer of trust estates of Elizabeth Stirling.

did.unittitle: Henry Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosure payable to Emma Maitland.

did.unittitle: C. Mifflin to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on engagement to Miss Tillinghast. Fisher and wife radiantly happy.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Ill feelings over Emma's will. Dolly still unwell.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on plans to be married. Visited the Stirlings at St. Andrews and stayed with Mrs. Gray's lodgings. Speaks of Andrew and Tom and The Smythe's.

did.unittitle: Club Stable to C. Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Bill for keeping horse.

did.unittitle: Richard Willing to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Business. Money owed by church. Taking tree down. Street through Townside Estate.

did.unittitle: H. Hollingsworth to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for new roof and enlarging Cooper's shop on Penn St.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledged remittance. References to marriage plans. Went to Golfer's Ball with Jane at St. Andrews. Comments on money and tottering Bank of United States. Harvest late but good. Lord Mayor entertaining distinguished Americans, Mr. & Mrs. Van Buren and Mr. Webster. Andrew won medal.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Congratulations on intended marriage. Discussion of Emma's estate.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dorothea's illness. Andrew's career. New neighbor, Mr. Lindsay in Mr. Binney's house.

did.unittitle: Horace Binney to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for notarized paper in case of Peters & Willing.

did.unittitle: _______ to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Request for Wilmington taxes.

did.unittitle: Richard Willing to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Re: loan (Wilmington & Balt.) Condition of Bank R.R.

did.unittitle: E. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Possible loss of property. Dolly in London for health. Andrew leaving for Swan River. Tom a favorite with Uncle Walter in Manchester. Sir James in London to dispose of land in Swan River Colony. Talked to James Maitland on money matters. Sir Fredericks death. Expect Jane to marry Mr. Cooke.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Dorothea's death. Andrew sails this month.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lady Maitland arriving from India. News of the Stirlings and Henry and Anna. Engagement to Miss Short.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explanation of why paper was not signed and sent sooner. Elizabeth's loss of Dolly. Willie visiting. James Maitland announced his marriage.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mary has measles. Elizabeth has gall stones and jaundice. James Maitland's marriage to Miss Short and disgust at his marrying soon after Emma's death. News of Andrew, William Stirling, Tom and the Murrays.

did.unittitle: Anne Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Concern over remittance which hasn't been received. James Maitland remarried. Would like to know what he got from Emma.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Receipt for remittance. Birth of a daughter to the Queen. News from St. Andrews. Willie and Mary had measles.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Winter remittance not yet received. Jane and Mr. Stirling going to England. Mr. Stirling to see Sir James. General news.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittance received. Mary, Willie, John and Emma had measles. Desire to go to Jersey for a year. Jane and Mr. Stirling in Manchester.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Financial business. General news - his marriage, his sister's marriage, game hunting.

did.unittitle: John Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Elizabeth's miscarriage. Sale of land. Letter to Mr. Hollingsworth.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Papers received, signed and sent to Robert Hare. Anxious to know what James Maitland had done. Meeting of British Association - Mr. Everett's speech. Trade dull and fear for suffering of the poor. Marquis of Waterford and wife thrown from carriage.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Visiting England. Saw the Queen and Prince Albert. Remittance received. Finances and family news.

did.unittitle: A. Murray to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittance received. Saw Queen and Prince Albert in Perth. Comments on America.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Questioning why no remittance from Hollingsworth. Willie nominated to Academy at Woolwich and to go to preparatory school until of age. Would like to have pieces of Mama's tea plate. Request for remittance from Charles Hare.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for statement of affairs. News of children.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Accident - overturned carriage fell on Mr. Stirling's foot. Riots in Philadelphia. Major Playfair - improvements in St. Andrews. News of Willie, Anne, Jane and Anna.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Alterations on house. Mr. Beckton died. To move to Manchester where John will work. Andrew to return home. Jane had daughter, Elizabeth.

did.unittitle: Thomas Biddle Co. to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Purchase of United States 5% stock.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Moved to Manchester in January. Visited Jane and Anna in Edinburgh. All sick on disagreeable voyage. Anne to return to England - Murray to be away 8 months. News of children, Jane, Anna, Willie and Andrew.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittance received. Henry and Anna visiting. Speaks of all the Stirlings, family and financial.

did.unittitle: _______ to Dr. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Account of wharfing arising from estate of T.M. Willing.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Mrs. Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Looking forward to your visit to Scotland. Sir James Stirling's desire to see them at Portsmouth. Mrs. John Powel's death. News of Ann, Jane, Anna and Willie.

did.unittitle: _______ to Mrs. Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Believe to be prescription.

did.unittitle: Thomas Watson to Dear Madam

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remedy for the tendency to perspiration.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Returned Power of Attorney. Needs money. Social - visit and family news.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledge of remittance for Mr. and Mrs. Murray.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Financial. Troubled countries - Scotland and Ireland. Smallpox at Lintrose.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittance received. Sale of Penn St. Estate. Family news.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Financial matters.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.p: Have examined and confirmed accounts, and request to have managed. News of Ann and Murray.

scopecontent.p: Remittance received. Union Canal & New Orleans bonds. Death of Mr. Meldrum.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Anxiety because remittance hsn't been received on transfer of property. Ann has rheumatic gout and will spend time at the Cape. Tom and the mill in Manchester. Willie at Woolwich. "Gold mania" in California. Emma to play in concert.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittance received. Financial problems.

did.unittitle: Thomas M. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.p: Mrs. Hall's legacy received. Trade and mill in England. Tempted to go to California.

scopecontent.p: Received share from Nancy's will. News of Willie and Ann. Intention of buying Miss Brown's house. Mention of "gold discovery". Elizabeth Stirling to Rebecca: Health and weather. Jane and Anna using Homeopathy Medicine. Battles in India. Lady Home's son, Sir John, ill. Agnes also ill.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.p: Sale of Penn St. Estate. Marriage of Mary Maitland and Captain Somerville.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Finances. Attending General Assembly in Edinburgh. Spoke to America's newly acquired state of California. Disturbances in Europe.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Family news, weather, financial and farms.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Questioning his state of affairs in Scotland and America.

scopecontent.p: Threat of spread of cholera. News of Jane, Anna, Tom, and Ann and Willie.

scopecontent.p: Social - family news. Cholera epidemic.

scopecontent.p: Remittance received. Family news of Henry and Anna, and Willie Stirling.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Remittance received. Purchased Miss Brown's property. Anxiety about Willie's bronchitis. Ann'e letter enclosed. Tore down building and making new courtyard. A. Murray to Dearest sister, 1850 January 12, Anxiety about Murray, but he arrived safely. Party at Government House with Sir Harry and Lady Smith. Mr. Stirling called. Murray has tiger skins but moths got into heads.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Visit to Edinburgh. News of Willie Stirling. Received bill of exchange. News of Henry and Anna.

scopecontent.p: Sent receipt Burton desired. Hope for America to buy wheat, and "free trade". Investments.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: William's death. William's will and concern about Tom and the mill. Letter of introduction to Mr. Purvis. Ann and Murray's visit.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Advice about taking mortgage on house. Willie ill in Halifax. Ferment about the Pope.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledged remittance. News about Willie, the Murray's and Jack. Completed garden and courtyard. Government's state of dislocation. Mary in Edinburgh for month with Jane.

scopecontent.p: Receipt of money from Tom.

scopecontent.p: Thank you for remittance. Mr. Murray died. New election for members of Parliament.

scopecontent.p: Mary's death. Willie's application for leave and doctor's care. Planning to go to Brussels. Ann still suffering from "gout". Aunt Nixon's death. Great instruction and pleasure from book by Edwards on the Redemption.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Acknowledgement of receipt of remittance. Mary Stirling's death. News of Willie Stirling, and Henry and Anna Maitland.

scopecontent.p: Feeling age. Mr. Stirling fainted. Walter's stage debut at 73. Tom's business arrangement with Uncle. Jack at home awaiting commission. Anxious about Willie.

scopecontent.p: Money received. Weather and farm crops. Wedding of William Meldrum and Miss Northege. Comments on Henry and Anna, Willie Stirling and Russia.

did.unittitle: Elizabeth Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.p: Visiting Tom who's comfortably settled, managing business himself, and Andrew living with him. Talking about visit to Philadelphia. News of Ann, Jack and Willie.

scopecontent.p: Discussion of Napoleon and the French. Acknowledgement of money. Henry and Anna.

scopecontent.p: Father's death. Mother's finances. Jack's commission as ensign.

scopecontent.p: In reply to a letter of consolation on loss of husband, and plans for immediate future.

scopecontent.p: Request to remit Emma's legacy to Willie for expenses in Horse Artillery. Fear Jack to be moved to Malta. Going to Scotland in April.

scopecontent.p: Remittance acknowledged. Part of house has to be roofed. Going to St. Andrews to "prove" will and value furniture, then to Elie for summer. Plans visits in autumn. John sailing for Malta. (Crimean War)

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.p: Thanks for interest on New Orleans bonds and land sales. War with Russia. Comments on Mr. Stirling's death. Henry and Anna.

scopecontent.p: Acknowledged remittance. Settled business at St. Andrews. John in Constantinople. Tom in Manchester. Walter in London will see Mr. and Mrs. Fallon. Fond of Elie. News of Ann and Murray, Willie and Walter Stirling.

did.unittitle: Thomas M. Stirling to Charles Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hoping to see Mr. and Mrs. Fallon. War, taxes, trade. Jack and Aunt Anna.

scopecontent.p: Brother John killed in war near Sebastopol.

scopecontent.p: John (son) killed by cannon shot in head. (Crimean War) Going to London, Cheltenham and then to St. Andrews with Emma.

scopecontent.p: Had influenza. News of Sally and Nacy Peters, and Ann. Talks of war and death of the Czar, Willie, Emma's visit to London, and Uncle Walter.

did.unittitle: J. Maitland to Charles Willing

scopecontent.p: Crimean war talk. Family news of John Stirling's death, Willie Stirling, Henry and Anna, and farming.

scopecontent.p: Interested in seeing Mr. Newman and Mr. Field. Trip abroad. Mentions Crimean War.

did.unittitle: Series II. Correspondence-Hare Family

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The largest of the seven series, it includes letters of the Hare, Binney and Beale families, written during the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries. Early correspondence includes letters by Robert Hare, Jr., one referring to steam engines, Horace Binney Hare about his Harvard education and service in the Civil War, and Horace Binney with his daughter Esther, who would marry Judge John Innes Clark Hare. The bulk of the series are letters by Dr. Horace Binney Hare, his wife, Emily Power Beale Hare, and their four children Charles Willing Hare, Esther Binney Hare, Horace Binney Hare, and Thomas Truxtun Hare. Highlighted are the children's schooling, social activities, service in World War I and travels in Europe. Also includes letters of Ellen Mary Cassatt, wife of Horace and niece of the artist Mary Cassatt. The Beale family correspondence includes financial and social news of Emily's siblings, Charles Willing Beale, Edward Fitzgerald Beale, Constance R. and Catherine C., whose son, Oliver Perry-Smith, the mountaineer, communicates with his aunt. Other noted correspondents include Dorothea L. Dix, Stuart Farrar Smith, Margaret MacVeagh, and President Theodore Roosevelt.

Badly in need of battery (6 guns with horses). See what can be done. Don't join a company unless Philadelphia is attacked. Along with other things requested, needs army pants and brandy flask.

scopecontent.p: (Part of a letter) Middleton's coming (rebels and cannot introduce them to anyone).

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Two love letters) Had trouble with horses and got scratched shin. John Binney and Archie visited.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Raining, so sawing wood, reading and fire-making with wet wood. Anxious to know when wedding will be.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Went for drive out Old York Rd. About friends, dogs and weather.

did.unittitle: Emily to Dr. H.B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Explaining they can't get married so soon. Couldn't go on riding party because of a cold. Mr. Smith, Mr. Lendall and Mr. Riviera called. Attie to be bridesmaid.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter)

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Saw Maria Fisher. Not going to John Binney's ordination. Cricket, weather, Fete, friends, and size of women fish-sellers.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Mother has come out from town. Have to go to medical meeting. Roads are in such a mess, and about little bay horse.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Not feeling well. Received "scent bag". Getting thinner. Thinks pocket was "picked" (lost money and other possessions).

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Much said about writing letters. Saw Aunt and Uncle and they are preparing to move out of town.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Went to Fete, and it was too cold, had a stupid time. Friends and social events.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Took a drive with Mother, birds on nest. Dr. Willing visited, but did not see him.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Worrying that you may be ill. Tockington (your Aunt's country place) being put in order. Going to Pepper's picnic at Chestnut Hill.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Charlie visited and we saw "Tockington" (looks lovely). Playing cricket this week.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Plans for going to Washington to bring you back. (Blue and white material enclosed)

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Pleased at having you coming back soon. Saw Emma Wood heard her tales. News of your family.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Had a lovely drive with Mother.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Headache. Disappointed in your cross letter.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Will see you tomorrow.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) After a wonderful afternoon and evening with you.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Successful journey thus far except for intense heat. (On way to Quebec and into woods)

did.unittitle: Emily to Horace

scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Maria and Minnie Montgomery visited.

scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Getting ready for expedition with Furness and Father. Got you a scarf.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Severe pain in face from abscess. Bought dozen pairs of gloves. Still intense heat.

scopecontent.p: Held over on trip so have to stay at Hotel. Going seal shooting.

did.unittitle: Horace to Emily P. Beale

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: (Love letter) Leaving Canada for the "States".

scopecontent.p: Account of arrival at Chicoutimi and trip to Ha! Ha! Bay. Were detained there by rain and fog. Trouble with French language. Anxious to get home.

scopecontent.p: Sorry can't be at your wedding. Best wishes.

scopecontent.p: Sent dress. Eliza caring for baby at night since Bridget left. Mr. Evans and General Meade dined here. Baby drinking from bottle.

scopecontent.p: Going for hayride to picnic at Pennypack. Father dining today at Chestnut Hill and tommorrow at Dr. Willing's. Emily still suffering from tooth.

scopecontent.p: Disappointed in no letters from home. Buying gifts. Sights.

scopecontent.p: War restricting movements. Comments on it. Very seriously considering "country life" for health. Trip has made him feel better.

scopecontent.p: On war, friends in Grindelwald, trying to be economical and travels. Norris again with them.

scopecontent.p: Roy and I missing you. Sending trunk and "The Waterloo Campaign" for your Mother. Montgomery's had fire in cellar.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.p: Elected to Episcopal Hospital. Roy missing you.

scopecontent.p: About loneliness, having dress made, Father swore in men with Album instead of Bible, and to go on duty at Hospital.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: All well. Missing you. Visited Hospital today.

scopecontent.p: Passes for Pennsylvania and Reading Railroads.

scopecontent.p: Lonely telling of love. Pleasant dinner at DaCosta's. About Emily Delafield and Attie. Negotiating for Cedar Grove for one year.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Happy New Year and birthday wishes. About plans for bringing you home. Gave lecture on Hydrogen and water. Saw your Uncle Charlie.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Went out to hospital today. Vacancy there - hope to be filled by Norris. Everyone missing you.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Hope you will come home soon. Afraid Norris won't be elected at hospital. Doesn't like Roy's cap makes him look like a girl.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Miss McFall was here about mourning dress you ordered. She needs more information. Norris was elected to hospital.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Missing you and general home news.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.p: Weather, loneliness, sent money, Roy, and received coffee pot from Mother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: So glad you're coming home.

scopecontent.p: Saw "Sinbad the Sailor". Snow. Friends and family. Working in laboratory.

scopecontent.p: Dinner party went off well. Advice to coax your Mother out often. Roy missing you.

scopecontent.p: Roy's impressions of your leaving. Advises to send for doctor for Mother.

scopecontent.p: Snow (plows and sweepers with 8 and 10 horses very busy). Busy working. Roy well.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.p: Ellen gone (fired for going away without asking). Charley wants to borrow money, don't know whether to lend it.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Make your Mother come up in autumn when "the advent" is expected.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.p: Walked today with Maria Fisher and Norris. News of your "upset" all over town. Social events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Explaining dismissal of Ellen and about money Charley wants to borrow. Eliza taking good care of Roy.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare (Emily)

scopecontent.p: General news and wants you to come back.

scopecontent.p: Secret - my Mother has made handsome Afghan for your mother. Friends visited.

scopecontent.p: Feels bad because you're away. Visited mine.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.p: All well and miss you. Minnie and Attie here to dinner.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Snow. Roy had sore throat. Can't imagine what Delafield has against him. Been house hunting with no luck. A good story is "Misunderstood".

scopecontent.p: Just a note to acknowledge letter.

scopecontent.p: General news of family and friends.

scopecontent.p: (Copy of letter) Letter of praise on what a good wife for grandson.

scopecontent.p: Finances.

scopecontent.p: Home news.

scopecontent.p: Home and family news.
