scopecontent.p: In reference to bill for lingerie.

did.unittitle: Mary Scott Montgomery to Miss Esther Binney Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Working for "American Fund for French Wounded" as a file clerk. What to expect if you come over to work. Need supplies from home too.

did.unittitle: Stuart Farrar Smith to Miss Esther Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thanks for all you did and will you send enclosed notice of our marriage to the Ledger. Margaretta MacVeagh and Stuart Farrar Smith's marriage - November 12.

scopecontent.p: Thanksgiving Day - place cards for the dinner.

scopecontent.p: Christmas and New Year's wishes.

scopecontent.p: Enjoyed Christmas dinner with you, and sorry I lost my voice. Enjoyed children's entertainment. Viola and Connie at Mrs. Coxe's dancing class ball.

scopecontent.p: Would be delighted to have the fur coat. Fire at our hotel and two cottages. New horse. Prescription for bronchitis medicine.

scopecontent.p: Thank you for box of bandages, etc.

scopecontent.p: Glad you are coming out. Please bring shirts, serge uniform, etc.

scopecontent.p: About Pullman memorandums.

scopecontent.p: Hope your tonsil will behave now. Talk of war work.

scopecontent.p: Glad Esther is better. In reference to Plunkett's enlistment.

scopecontent.p: Memo of experience in handling horses.

did.unittitle: Mary Helen Cadwalader to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Saw in paper of Willing's appointment as head of civilian experts on the war. Suppose Horace is longing to get to the Front to be with the victorious troops.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. H.B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Finally quartered in War Department - getting settled.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to enclosed letter from Horace on getting good mess sergeant and on Mother coming out here. Will let you know if I find anything about movement of the Cavalry. Saw Cousin May and Ambassador from Argentina and his wife. Pleasant living conditions, but looking into apartment.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Going house hunting - description of house now living in. Cousin May would be delighted to have you come - could look the various houses over (in view of your moving to Washington). Servant question. Heard that Cavalry regiments are being turned into Artillery regiments which Horace dislikes. Send some vegetables down from Radnor.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Description of house on P Street and the Davis house. Don't come down while it's still hot.

did.unittitle: Willing to Miss Esther B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: In reference to monthly checks. About trying to secure a transfer for Horace. Dined with Truxton Beale. On work here. Do not think it wise for you to go to Chicago to see Horace.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclosing letter from Horace - so interested in troop - 316th Cavalry being made an artillery regiment - feels dreadful as all commanders are fitted for cavalry and have been training thoroughly. Copy of my reply - authorities see immediate need for artillery (an explanation of the whole affair). Vegetables arrived in first class condition.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Horace's regiment to be organized at Camp Jackson, South Carolina. Hoping Horace can arrange a furlough. Attended meeting where Secretary of War made an address. Entertaining members of committee at luncheon at Truxtun Beale's house.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Coming home for a few day's rest. Intense heat here.

did.unittitle: Margaretta to Miss Esther Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Telegram - much love and all well here.

did.unittitle: Emily Power Hare to Mother

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: How much you have meant to me all my life.

did.unittitle: Charles to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Such a relief to know Mother is improving. On Margaret and Willing. Looks like war if going to be over soon.

did.unittitle: Grace Meeker to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sent photos of Mrs. Ryerson's garden and article which appeared in Chicago Tribune. So glad to have met you and your daughter.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Horace spent Saturday night and Sunday with me. About securing house. Got Plunkett and other men for Horace.

did.unittitle: Maria M. Coxe to Mrs. Horace Binney Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sorry to hear of Mrs. Beale's illness. Comments on the family, war, and memories of when we were young.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. H.B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Picture of him that was in the Inquirer on his birthday. Nice having Esther here - looking at houses to rent and will be happy when you are here.

scopecontent.p: Sympathy letters on Mother's death. (Mrs. Beale - September 14, 1918)

scopecontent.p: Grandmama's death and funeral.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Enclose copy of telegram from General Pershing on death of Walker Beale in action. House is very comfortable and sure you will be delighted with your room.

scopecontent.p: Glad for you, but sorry for me that you moved to Washington. Rumors of peace last Thursday. Does Willing still admire Secretary of War so?

scopecontent.p: Thought Katharine had influenza but nothing but a severe cold. Men slowly straggling back from the war.

scopecontent.p: At Clark's place. Hunting here and then will try fishing in Florida. Hope Horace has decided to leave the Army.

scopecontent.p: Wrote Mrs. Coolidge I could not dine. Leaving here for Daytona, Florida for fishing and sea bathing. Have enjoyed hunting here. (Jasmine flowers enclosed)

scopecontent.p: Had examination at Johns Hopkins know what trouble is and how it can be cured. Will sail around July 17th. Glad to have Horace with me - hope he will have his leg taken care of. Coming to Philadelphia Thursday.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Glad to hear you are in Paris and saw in Ledger you had arrived at Brest. Paul working on car - says it will be good for several years. Dined at Ned's. News of family and friends.

scopecontent.p: Detailed account of what he's been doing since arrival in France - landing, night trip to Paris, sales to France, visited General Pershing and Herbert Hoover, and setting up headquarters and living quarters.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Detailed account of trip to scene of fighting (full description) - scenery, the actual battles, restoration, etc.

scopecontent.p: Everything here politically seems restless and chaotic. May Bayard visiting. Motor repaired and we lunched with Mrs. MacVeagh. Horace now at Seattle.

scopecontent.p: Good luck. In motor accident. (Enclosed clippings from papers on your job, and one in reference to the complications in will of Samuel Chew.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Delighted with your interesting letters. Comments on distributing food. May enclosed note in case you'd like to call on the de Bryas' who are so near you.

scopecontent.p: Child's letter.

scopecontent.p: Have sprained leg. Lily Reading very, very ill.

did.unittitle: ______ (M. Bayard?) to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.p: Glad ring was found. Going to Whitehall. Do you want to sell more necklaces?

did.unittitle: Mother to C. Willing Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Will guard your letters - you have such a talent for writing - these will go down in history. Esther visiting Louise Wood in Dublin and I am going to Narragansett. Horace wrote from San Francisco. May Bayard visited for ten days.

did.unittitle: Horace to Miss Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Please send money.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Detailed account of trip to Brussels and other towns (crossing some of the most interesting fighting areas in the war) and...

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Have decided to go round with the boat "Dolaura" under Canadian flag. Argument against you - something about not getting on better about the service.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Interviews with Mr. Crowell, General Pershing, Prime Minister of Greece, Lloyd Griscom, Frank Polk and other government business matters. Opinions on what government should be doing on high cost of living at home and helping war torn countries. Will spend week in London.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Storm at sea on way to Acapulco. Intense heat. Have seen many forms of sea life. (Postcards)

did.unittitle: Horace to C.W. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: On his trip to Alaska and now going to Canal Zone.

did.unittitle: Esther to C. Willing Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Met Mother here. Social activities and friends. Bathing. Visit to Louise.

did.unittitle: Mother to C. Willing Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: What we're doing here, friends, etc. Politics chaotic - on Mayor of Philadelphia "should be sorry to see honest men put in among that den of thieves". Expect Horace home soon.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Complete narration on government business matters - with a Mr. Feline, Boston merchant; M. Clemenceau and M. Louecher of the French government; and Herbert Hoover. More accounts of visitations to French towns.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Description of Acapulco and merchants selling their wares in boats about yacht.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Voyage to here from Acapulco. About getting coal. Interesting stories on Mexican government, people and country.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Description of trip to England. Government busniness matters. Theatre. Comments on the Peace Treaty. Coming home soon.

did.unittitle: Horace to Miss Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Got coal at Corinto. Difficult piece of work getting boat in and difficulties of paying for coal. Story of the English helping Dewey after the Battle of Manilla (Postcards and Mexican money) (Map of course into harbor)

scopecontent.p: Willing so much better, and I have recovered my strength fast. We'll be home first part of the week.

scopecontent.p: Good for us here. Weather, fishing. Write about Truxtun who is still in bed.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.p: Glad you are going to Washington. Doctor here treating my wound. Fishing. About Truxton and your keeping the children. H. playing golf. About apartment.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Fishing poor. Wound much improved. Heard from Julia Grant who is helping Russian refugees. Would like to be a Senator "but not like most of those at present who put Country last and politics first".

C.W. Beale to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Constance in Philadelphia. Interested to hear Horace and wife going to recently acquired Chateau in France. On Oliver, Commodore Truxton, Granny, Grandfather Beale, Uncle Edward and Spanish friend from Ecuador. On "answering our own prayers" (subconcious).

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.p: Will land tomorrow - smooth voyage. The baby and Cardinal Dougherty and others on board.

did.unittitle: E.M. Hare to C. Willing Hare

scopecontent.p: Thank you for all you did to get us off. Baby's doll admired by all the children on board. Nice servants - even good to the dogs.

did.unittitle: Ellen Mary Hare to Mrs. Horace Binney Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thank you for grapes and fruit - baby drinking orange juice. Ellen Mary a peerless sailor and owing to her we met most of the passengers - she especially attracted Cardinal Dougherty.

scopecontent.p: Poetic letter and one in French, and poem "The Censer".

scopecontent.p: Delighted to hear you are coming over with the Hutchinsons. Quiet here. Katharine is with us - she met Lindbergh. About stone not being delivered. The baby well.

scopecontent.p: Bon voyage gifts. Boat nice. Shall miss you.

scopecontent.p: Esther well and we're looking forward to our trip in England.

scopecontent.p: Trying to change passage to an earlier date. Pleasant here with Horace, Ellen and the baby who is a constant joy to all. Going to Paris again and may return here with Margaretta. Joyful Truxtun Jr. got into Yale.

scopecontent.p: Am enjoying myself. Have two more weeks to go. Have been admitted to Yale.

did.unittitle: Mother to Miss Esther Hare

scopecontent.p: Enjoyed photos of baby and house and grounds. Truxtun saw Dempsey fight in New York. Going to Bar Harbor so we'll miss seeing K. and girls return. Truxtun's building. About Wood's daughter-in-law's death. Winston Churchill's book. George a very good servant.

did.unittitle: Esther to Mrs. H.B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Horace and I saw K. and the girls off. Had delightful two weeks at Beaufresne. Can't seem to get an earlier passage. Want to see Margaretta. Shopping. Engagements with friends and family.

scopecontent.p: Could not get cabins yesterday, so staying there on way to Palerno. Keep children studying.

scopecontent.p: April 10. Sightseeing. Children studying French and adults Italian. Desirous of having Esther painted by Gordigiani, but charges too high. Plans for either meeting children in England or at home.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: June 23. She and mother went to your mother and father's where things were sad. Went to Mrs. Crawford's where little boys were speaking "pieces". Your Mother "broke down" saying a prayer for you.

did.unittitle: Emily to H.B. Hare, M.D.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: July 20. War between France and Russia. Mr. Robeson and Andrew sailed over. Food bad, but bathing lovely.

did.unittitle: Emily to Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: December 28. Trying to comfort Mamma. Feels bad about Eddie going so far from home. Instructions to Mrs. McFall to make dress.

did.unittitle: Emily to Horace Binney Hare, M.D.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: August 4. Went to church. Your mother visited. Baby well, but not Roy. Sad about leaving here. Visited Chestnut Hill.

did.unittitle: Emily to Horace Binney Hare, M.D.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: August 14. Roy improving. Went to city and ward for Philadelphia - "smells". Weather hot. Charlie doing well at mine, but Maria ill.

did.unittitle: Emily to Horace B. Hare, M.D.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: January 3. Not necessary to come for her. Visited Aunt Emily. Teaching Katy. Feeling wretchedly gloomy.

did.unittitle: Emily to Horace

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: December 31. Trunk has not come. Request for beef tea, money and that you write Charlie.

did.unittitle: Emily to Dr. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: February 23. Mamma not at all well, but am coming home. Last night of carnival a beautiful sight.

did.unittitle: Emily to Dr. H.B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: August 3. Can't understand why spending so much time in London, and afraid the war will prevent traveling in Europe. Social events. Went sailing. Does not want to return to Cedar Grove. Roy walking by chairs. Request for stockings from London and underbodies, petticoats, silk stockings, cravats and lace shawl from Paris.

did.unittitle: William H. Hare (cousin) to H.B. Hare, M.D.

scopecontent.p: May 14. Leaving home - journey to Washington.

scopecontent.p: Making "date" for 5, and if you can get Maria to put off trip until Friday, will accompany you.

did.unittitle: ______ to Emily

scopecontent.p: (part of a letter) Behaving badly, feet hurt, talk about friends, and invitation to visit.

scopecontent.p: July 13. Trying to comfort. Connie and Kate. Charlie and Maria want them to visit. Plans for the summer. Horse for Eddie. July 21. Advising to plan for trip to Europe in Spring and go away a while this summer. About cottage near you.

scopecontent.p: Tuesday evening. Writing poetry. John Hoffman and Helen. Sandy. Come Saturday and bring Bessie.

scopecontent.p: May 18. (part of a letter). Expecting quantity of cousins and relations from the South. Afraid soon will have to give up room and old dresses to them.

scopecontent.p: Wednesday evening. Friendly letter.

scopecontent.p: Monday evening. Went riding today and saddle slipped over horse's head when he stepped in swamp and I landed floundering in mud.

scopecontent.p: Saturday afternoon. "Raging headache". No chance M.J.I.'s coming. If Sandy comes will write again.

scopecontent.p: Thursday. Tells of catching sailfish and picture of fish enclosed. Dr. Jack is there and looked him over and thought him in good shape.

scopecontent.p: Prescription for X-ray of both hips.

scopecontent.p: Thank you for handkerchiefs.

did.unittitle: Emily (niece) to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.p: Tuesday. Thank you for china.

scopecontent.p: Trying to improve theirselves with reading.

scopecontent.p: Friday. Thinks it wise you do not attempt lake trip, but he is going to take it. Asks Esther to get leather portfolio in Florence.

scopecontent.p: July 16. Visiting H. and E.M. in Europe. Detailed day of baby's (E.M.) schedule.

scopecontent.p: Wednesday. Plans for Holy Week in Rome to go to cermonies at churches, and to see the Cardinal and Pope. Description of view from hotel room. Visits, guests and sights. Purchased lace and silks. Make appointment in Rome for coiffeur.

did.unittitle: Truxtun Hare, Jr. (grandson) to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Friday. Glad to be home from France, but really lived a French life while there. Thank you for letter and check.

scopecontent.p: May 23. Best wishes for trip abroad.

did.unittitle: Mother to Mrs. Horace B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: May 31. On return to Bloomingdale. So busy. Baby. Maria's sewing. Katie "fixed up" for May Ball. Quite ill with cold. Went to church one time since return and felt so welcomed by friends. Ned Pendleton divorced and married again.

did.unittitle: M.A.B. to Mrs. H.B. Hare

did.unittitle: Mamma Hare to Mrs. H.B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Your Mother's and my plans to visit you in Georgia. John, the coachman, ran over a child's leg, but resulted only in bad bruise.

did.unittitle: Horace to Mrs. H.B. Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Good Friday. Description of hotel, rooms and food - not a place for women. (part of a letter).

scopecontent.p: April 23. Letter to Mother.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wednesday. Visiting the Livingstons. Going to steam down Hudson. While riding to call at Astor's, vicious dog tried to bite, and avoiding it, broke wheel.

scopecontent.p: March 14. Child's letter to sister.

did.unittitle: Willing to Mamma

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sunday. (part of a letter). Fishing with Grandpapa, and went for tarpon.

scopecontent.p: Friday. About the Wrights. Mrs. Wright wants to meet you in Paris.

scopecontent.p: Invitation to walk.

did.unittitle: Mother (M.A.B.) to Emily

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: July 28. Home news. Received letter from Ned and Maria describing the falling of the bell tower of St. Mark's in Venice. Playing in Mr. Hare's tent with Hope and Lena. Henrietta Brown's wedding. Enjoying staying with the Hare's, but must leave when heat comes. Wishes you could see Mark Twain - Charlie like him so much.

did.unittitle: Mother to Emily

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Wednesday night. Thanking you for two birds (if they were from you). Had hoped to see you at tea, but was kept later at Katy's than expected.

scopecontent.p: Thank you for gloves.

scopecontent.p: August 8. Had a delightful time at Rye Beach.

did.unittitle: Esther to Mamma

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: July 4. Tested colt before going for a drive by setting off fire crackers under his nose. "Duckie's" prizes for sports. Dinner and fun last night. New clothes. Going to fireworks tonight.

did.unittitle: E.M. Hare to Mrs. Horace Binney Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: August 7. Glad to hear of safe arrival and thank you for gifts, poem, vegetables and cream. Said Kate Hutchinson met a man on Isle of Guernsey, hereditary cupbearer to king, his family having held the office since 1350.

scopecontent.p: Friday. After boarding ship found could get a whole cabin. Saw runins of Messina. Met Dr. Norris with E. and Nancy.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Beale's first baby; Picture of room from Sam Powel's House; Picture of royal family; Death of Miss Mary Edith Powel; Review of "Murder in the Cathedral" by T.S. Eliot; Map of Italy showing "How the Allies Menace Wavering Italy from the Sicilian Airfields" ; Lindbergh's goodwill flight from Washington to Central and South America; "The Bachelor's Ball"; "Good Friday in Albania"; Cricket Match at Manheim (Philadelphia vs. Australia); Article on Captain Hare on Penn team; The McLean dinner; United States will not buy ships from belligerent Nations, Dacia sails, facing seizure and says United States should join Kaiser; Mutt and Jeff cartoon strip; Maggie and Jiggs cartoon; "Keeping up with the Joneses" - cartoon; Picture of Colonel Edward de V. Morrell's coach; Picture of first prize winner at the Flower Show Garden Exhibit; Picture of Charlemagne Tower, former ambassador to Germany and Count J.H. Von Bernstorff, German Ambassador to United States; Our manners in Public; Mr. Blaine's future (out of politics until public sentiment calls for him); Rev. R.H. Gurley to marry Miss Theodora Eldredge; C. Willing Hare in War Post; Paris Press Lauds Britain and Prince (Edward's abdication); Dr. Mercer Dies (noted scientist); Britain's Own Verdict (King Edward's abdication); Work of Philadelphia Doctors Shown (Peritonitis, Appendicitis experiments); Picture of girl and horse; Picture of man and dog; "The Real Issue" on state Dry and Blue Laws.

Series III. Bound Volumes

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The bound volumes include, among others: Robert Hare letterbooks (1824-1825, 1841-1857), estate records, and laboratory expense accounts (1818-1860); G. H. Hare's journal or log of cruises aboard the U.S. United States (1841) and U.S. Flint (1845); Horace Binney Hare's 1862 journal of his trip to San Francisco. There are account books and accounts (1754-1795) kept by Thomas Willing; accounts of the controversy over the estate of John Innes Clark; and records of the First Colored Wesley Methodist Church of Philadelphia (receipt book, 1820-1848; minute book, 1827-1844). There are also Philadelphia court records, and minutes of the Common Council of the city, 1832. Of particular note, a map of Hare Street in Philadelphia between Schuylkill River and Darby Road (Letters. Clark and Robert Hare, 1842-1857).

did.unittitle: Receipt Book. Estate of Clement Plumsted. Willing & Morris Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Book A. 1745-1746. Records - estate of Clement Plumstead. 1760-1765. Receipt Book - Willing, Morris & Co. (Receipts for such things as rum, negroes, flour, rice, sugar, pork, molasses, gunpowder, hay, etc.) Receipts for use of ships, pilotage, losses on ships, etc. Receipt of May 2, 1763 for shares of prize money from privateer ship Hero's cruise.

did.unittitle: Account Book. Thomas Willing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Book B. 1754-1758. Accounts - Thomas Willing (executor of estate of Chas. Willing) (acct. for Dr. Benjamin Franklin) 1756-1761. Records for houses. 1778-1786. Accounts - Wm. Bingham Account 1781. Ground rents due and unpaid to T.W. Annual rents due to T.W. Two shares loose in book with Seal of the Bank of North America. Notations made throughout book such as, June 18, 1778 - Gen'l Clinton with rear of British Army left Phila. at 5 o'clock a.m. to cross river at Gloucester Point. Mar. 18, 1779 - This day I weighed at the Rope Walk 173 lbs. (P.M.) Apr. 29, 1782 - Old Robert Montgomery left me yesterday. Sept. 14, 1783 - My friend and partner, Samuel Inglis, died yesterday morning about 1 o'clock of a putrid sore throat. Sept. 10, 1784 - New wharf sunk by Thos. Davis. Old pier repaired in fall of 1783.

did.unittitle: Accounts of Thomas Willing & Estate of Capt. Sam Appowen

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1754 Dec. 12-1760 Jan. 16. Accounts of Thos. Willing. 1767 June 10-1773 July 20. Accounts of Estate of Capt. Sam Appowen (Thos. Willing, Administrator). 1773 March 11. Printed letters - admission of Thos. Morris into firm of Willing, Morris & Co., and offering best services by this house of business.

did.unittitle: Accounts of Thomas Willing, Thomas Willing Francis or William & Francis

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1789-1795. Accounts - (presumably those of Thos. Willing, Thos. Willing Francis or Willing & Francis) Notation inside cover - Maker & No. of watch, James McCabe, London, No. 1958. Loose papers - notes with names, dates, murders, man buried alove, a fruit of England much like a rotten apple, etc.

did.unittitle: Accounts of Philip Wilson (Mariner)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1800 March 21-1811 June 29. Accounts of Philip Wilson (Marnier) 1805 Jan. 23. Instrument of Protest - Ship Mars - storm on voyage from Bourdeaux to Phila. Had to go to port in Ireland. 1805-1806. Instruments of Attestation - testifying to condition of cargo of ship after storm damage, condition of cargo after storage, condition of ship after storm, ship in unfit condition to proceed to sea, estimate of expenses for repairs, and testifying to more damages and additional expenses. 1805 Feb. 4. Letter to Capt. Philip Wilson from Barclay and Salkeld, London. Advising to sell cargo to pay for repairs. 1805 March 14. Letter to Capt. Philip Wilson from Barclay & Salkeld. Again advising to sell cargo for expenses for repairs. 1804 June 25. Letter to Capt. Philip Wilson from owner of ship Mars, D.W. Coxe, Phila., advising cargo pledged to Govt. of U.S. to go to Antwerp, and do not anchor in English port. Then proceed to Bordeaux for cargo of wines, etc. to go to Phila. Request to be advised of all movements. Letter to Barclay & Salkeld, London, from D.W. Coxe, Phila. Requesting assistance to Capt. Wilson if necessary. 1806 March 16. Letter to Capt. Philip Wilson, Kinsale, Ireland from D.W. Coxe, Phila. Orders to immediately send Protest Paers, and to ship cargo by another vessel. Angry because cargo was sold to pay expenses.

did.unittitle: Records of Wharf
Account of Bank of United States [Letters by Thomas Willing, in reference to Bingham estate]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1810. Account of Bank of U.S. (account of Thomas Mayne Willing and others with Bank of U.S.) 1821 June 6. Schedule of personal property of Charles Willing Hare. 1821 June 18. Letter to John H. Powel, from Thos. M. Willing. Delivery of bonds from John Savage in reference to Bingham estate. 1821 June 21. Letter to John Hare Powel, from Thos. M. Willing. Business statements in reference to Bingham estate. 1821 June 25. Letter to Charles King, New York, from T.M. Willing. In ref. to claims of Insurance Co. of N.A. and other claims being taken care of by other agents. 1821 July 4. Letter to Alexander Baring, London, from T.M. Willing. In reference to Bingham estate, about Mr. Hare's lunacy and demands on estate, and Wm. Bingham's behavior. 1821 Sept. 1. Letter to Mrs. Henry Clymer from Thos. M. Willing. Details on remittance. 1821 Oct. 3. Letter to John H. Powel from T.M. Willing. Reference to Landsdowne estate. 1821 Ocr. 3. Letter to Robt. Gilman, Baltimore, from T.M. Willing. In reference to Bingham estate - suggestion of asking Horace Binney to serve as new trustee. 1821 Oct. 8. Letter to Richard Peters from T.M. Willing. In reference to brother William's 3 children, Thomas, Richard, and Sarah. 1821 Oct. 8. Letter to John Stirling, London, from T.M. Willing. Arrangements to furnish loan for business, and experiment on imitation Canton Cloth. 1821 Oct. 17. Letter to Henry Clymer from T.M. Willing. (check enclosed) 1821 Oct. 23. Letter to John H. Powel from T.M. Willing. Transferring stock under Bingham estate. 1821 Oct. 26. Letter Robt. Gilman, Baltimore, from T.M. Willing. In reference to settlement of copartnership accts. under Bingham estate, Mr. Binney declined being trustee, and new trustee has to be appointed since Mr. Hare declared insane. 1821 Nov. 6. Letter to Mrs. Elizabeth Powel, Chestnut St., from T.M. Willing. Account of estate of Brother Richard Willing. 1821 Nov. 6. Letter to Mrs. Ann Willing Morris, Germantown, from T.M. Willing. In reference to money due under estate of Richard Willing and interest on bond of Abby Willing. 1821 Nov. 9. Letter to Capt. E.M. Donaldson of the ship Caledonia, from T.M. Willing. About experimental sale of 8 pieces of imitation Canton Cloth and invest proceeds in tea. 1821 Nov. 12. Letter to Thomas Peters from T.M. Willing. In reference to lands granted to James Willing and lands belonging to the estate of Mr. Nixon. 1821 Nov. 19. Letter to John H. Powel from T.M. Willing. About settlement of Robert Gilman's copartnership under Bingham estate. 1821 Nov. 26. Letter to Chartier DeLotbinciere, Montreal, Canada, from T.M. Willing. In reply on behalf of Wm. Bingham, as his guardian, in reference to marriage. 1821 Nov. 26. Letter to Mr. Wm. Crammond. Trust fund cannot be touched. 1821 Nov. 30. Letter to Robert Gilman, Baltimore. In reference to Bingahm estate. 1821 Dec. 5. Deliverance of the assignment of John Savage of certain Bonds and Mortgages to T.M. Willing & Robt. Gilman. Delivery made to John H. Powel. 1822 Jan. 1. Letter to Wm. Bingham from T.M. Willing. Release as guardian, trust and deed for conducting affairs, and account of inheritance. 1822 Jan. 3. Letter to Chartier DeLotbinciere, from T.M. Willing. Explaining estate of Wm. Bingham to his intended father-in-law. 1822 Jan. 3. Letter to Wm. Bingham from T.M. Willing. paid expenses of journay to Montreal, and advising amount available monthly for 6 months. 1822 Jan. 8. Letter to John Stirling, London, from T.M. Willing. Sending money loaned for business and conditions. 1822 Jan. 9. Letter to Baring Bros. Co., London, from T.M. Willing. Certificates of stock to cover bill drawn for loan for John Stirling. 1822 Jan. 23. Letter to Francis Baring, from Thos. M. Willing. Death of Mr. Gilman, trustee for Bingahm estate, suggestions of new trustee, Mr. Richards. Mr. Joseph Ingersoll has consented to replace Mr. Hare. 1822 Feb. 6. Letter to Mrs. Elizabeth Harrison from T.M. Willing. Sending trust deed to be read and returned - in reference to father's estate. 1822 Feb. 6. Letter to Mr. Edward Larner, Chestnut St., from T.M. Willing. Do not make plate for W. Bingham. 1822 Feb. 12. Letter to John H. Powel, from T.M. Willing. In reference to Maine lands and settlers on lands under will of Mr. Bingham, and inability to act until 2 new trustees are appointed. 1822 Feb. 20. Letter to Ebenezer Foote, Delaware Co., New York. Proposing selling of some New York lands. 1822 Mar. 6. Letter to John H. Powel, Harrisburg, from Thos. M. Willing. Refers to Mr. C.W. Hare's indebtedness and claims to Binham estate. 1822 Feb. 26. Letter to John Richards, Boston, from T.M. Willing. In reference to appointment as trustee to Bingham estate, and need for legislation in the various states where property is located to make division of estate. 1822 Mar. 16. Letter to Francis Baring from T.M. Willing. Refers to full account of personal effects of Bingham estate. 1822 March 19. Letter to Robt. Gilman, Baltimore, from T.M. Willing. In reference to Bingham estate. 1822 March 21. Letter to Henry Drinker, from T.M. Willing. In reference to taxes on land in Bradford Co., Pa., and wish to sell these lands. 1822 March 13. Letter to Thos. Peters, Phila., from T.M. Willing. In reference to payment of taxes on land in Armstron and Venango Counties, Pa. of heirs of Mr. Nixon and Capt. James Willing. 1822 March 25. Letter to Thos. Peters, Phila., from T.M. Willing. Authorization to sell land in Vanago Co. granted to Capt. James Willing. 1822 Mar. 30 Letter to Mrs. Susan Byrd, Abington, Gloucester Court House, Gloucester Co., Virginia, from T.M. Willing. About interest due on trust funds of children and request for receipt. 1822 Mar. 29. Letter to Alex. Baring, London, from T.M. Willing. Advising of Joseph Ingersoll and John Richards as trustees in place of Mr. Gilman who died, and Mr. Hare declared a lunatic, and need of state legislation to act. About papers necessary from European trustees, methods of division of estate and investments. 1822 Apr. 4. Letter to Alex. Baring, London, from Thos. M. Willing. About Wm. Bingham's estate, and his own statement of inability to manage it. Baring and Willing to act as trustees. 1822 Jan. 31. Letter to Wm. Bingham, Montreal, Canada, from T.M. Willing. In reply to letter about yearly settlement on wife and expenses for furnishing house. 1822 Jan. 25. Letter to Wm. Bingham, Montreal, Canada, from T.M. Willing. Authorization to draw $8000 for furnishing house. 1822 April 19. Letter to Henry Drinker at Stoddardsville, near the Falls of Lehigh, Luzerne, Pa., from T.M. Willing. In reference to sale of lands, with details and inquiries as to settlers, previous sales and taxes. 1822 Apr. 28. Letter to Wm. Bingham, Montreal, from T.M. Willing. In reference to a visitor trying to obtain money unjustly. 1822 May 11. Letter to Mrs. Powel, Chestnut St., Phila., from T.M. Willing. Refers to claim on Mr. Clymer's estate. 1822 May 30. Letter to Dr. N. Chapman, Phila., from T.M. Willing. Paying accounts of himself, Wm. Bingham and his father's. 1822 June 6. Letter to Ramdaloll Day, Calcutta, from T.M. Willing. In reference to account. 1822 July 9. Letter to Baring Bros. Co., London, from T.M. Willing. Accounting of Bingham estate. 1822 July 22. Letter to Mr. Edward Tharp, Camden, New Jersey. Refers to ground rent on Wind Mill Island. 1822 August 17. Letter to Wm. Rawle, Phila., from T.M. Willing. Balance due estate of Mr. Lewis. 1822 Sept. 12. Letter to Henry Baring, London, from T.M. Willing. Power of attorney and act of appointment received. Will try to effect speedy division of Bingham estate and information on how they are going to do so. Comments on Wm. Bingham, and discussion of Mr. Hare's claim on estate. 1818 December 23. Account of Lansdowne Estate with Executors of Wm. Bingham. 1822 July 7. Loose note in book - to W. Jordan, Insurance Co. of North America, from T.M. Willing. Sending copy of condemnation of Ship Mount Vernon.

did.unittitle: Regarding controversy over John Innes Clark Estate

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1811 Feb. 10. Letter to "My dear Sister" from O. Kane, Providence. Accounting of estate. (John Innes Clark) 1816 Nov. 15. Letter to Mrs. Lydia Clark from O. Kane, Providence. In reference to individual account under estate and request all get together to make settlement. 1817 Feb. 5. Letter to Mrs. Lydia Clark from O. Kane. Information on estate. 1817 March 9. Letter to Col. Ephraim Bowen from Oliver Kane. In reference to settlement of estate. 1817 March 10. Letter to Oliver Kane from Ephraim Bowen, Pawtuxet. Agreeable to examination of accounts of estate and is satisfied with partial settlement of accounts to Harriet. 1817 March 12. Letter to Robt. Hare from Oliver Kane. Controversy over settlement of estate. 1817 Apr. 4. Letter to Robt. Hare from O. Kane, Providence. In reference to controversy over agreement of settlement in August, 1811. (With Note referring to Mr. Kane secretly taking $20,000 for compensation). 1817 July 23. Letter to "Dear Sir" from Oliver Kane. Proposal to convey property instead of cash. Note from Sarah Gibbs - saying all letters in this book with her signature superscribed are authentic copies. 1817 July 23. Letter to Oliver Kane from Mrs. Clark. Request for payment of legacy. 1817 July 24. To "My dear Madam" (Mrs. Clark) from Oliver Kane. Refusal to settle estate until court decision. 1817 Summer. To Oliver Kane from Mrs. Clark. Discussing belief that property should be put in her hands. 1817 July 30. To Mrs. Clark from Oliver Kane. Proposal to submit case to Mr. Searle and Mr. Burgess for consideration. 1817. To Oliver Kane from Lydia Clark. Accepts proposal of calling on lawyers, but would choose her own, Judge Burrill and Mr. Whipple. 1817 August. To Mrs. Clark from Oliver Kane. Strong objection to Judge Burrill and Mr. Whipple. 1817. To O. Kane from Mrs. Clark. Proposing amicable settlement of their disagreements, and pleaing for legacy. 1817 August 7. To Mrs. Clark from O. Kane. Indignation at charges. If S. Court would make decision, would settle. To O. Kane from Mrs. L. Clark. Demand for the money. 1817 August 11. To Mrs. Clark from O. Kane. Explaining what has to be done before settlement. To O. Kane from Mrs. Clark. Accusing of injustice. Will let him choose 3 men out of 6 to referee. 1817 August 19. To Mrs. Clark from O. Kane. Will liquidate legacy under bond. Insists on examination of accounts. To O. Kane from Mrs. Clark. Will name 6 men and choose 3 to referee affairs. Questions compensation taken, and Mr. Hare's settlement. 1817 Oct. 7. To O. Kane from Mrs. Clark (with passage in reference to house expenses to Mrs. Hare's writing.) Request to see power of attorney and desires check for $500. 1817 Oct. 9. To Mrs. L. Clark from O. Kane. Check enclosed for $200. J.B. Murray case and effect on estate. Request for house expenses of Mrs. Hare. Power of attorney void, but important if settlement od 1811 is contested. 1817 Nov. 17. To Mrs. Clark from O. Kane. Reasons why he could be held responsible for sums advanced. 1817 Nov. 25. To O. Kane from Mrs. L. Clark. Again proposing legacy be paid and request for power of attorney. 1811 March 1. Part of letter to Miss Harriet Clark from O. Kane. Mrs. Clark never to be destitute, but if she accepted money from estate, she would lose her right of Dower. 1817 Nov. 29. To Mrs. L. Clark from O. Kane. Informing that payment of legacy and settlement of estate should be simultaneous. Proposal of Arbitration - to decide differences between Oliver Kane and wife and Robt. Hare and wife under will of John Innes Clark. 1817 Oct. 7. To O. Kane from R. Hare. Belief Mrs. Clark should be paid, and reference to his claims. 1817 Dec. Copy of original bond given by Mrs. L. Clark to Robert and Harriet Hare ($25,000) 1818 Jan. 27. Copy of part of letter to R. Hare from John Whipple. In reference to Dalton Estate. 1818 Feb. 10. (?) (making more profit on estate) 1818 Mar. 6. Copy of part of letter to Mrs. Clark from Dr. Pardon Bowen. Wine in good order. Feels advisable to accede to Mr. Kane's conditions. 1818 Apr. 2. Copy of letter to Mrs. Clark from Dr. Wm. Bowen. Propses Mr. Hare give Bond required by Mr. Kane. 1819 Mar. 10. Copy of letter to Mr. R. Hare from J. Whipple, Providence. In reference to O. Kane concealing knowledge. 1818 Mar. 25. Letter to Mrs. Clark from C. Kane. O. Kane leaving state and denying accusations against him and making accusations of famiy. Letter to O. Kane from Mrs. Clark. Strong accusations in handling estate of Mr. Clark. 1818 Sept. 28. Copy of part of letter to Mrs. Clark from Oliver Kane. Charge for firewood. 1819 Sept. 28. Statement of Mrs. Lydia Clark saying she acted under her brothers advice, not Mr. Robt. Hare's, and urgency for payment was for independence. 1818 Jan. 8. Copy of Deed to Harriet Hare from E. Bowen and O. Kane. Release of property in Providence. 1818 July 6. Col. Bowen's explanation of his oath. (Does not know whether accounts of O. Kane are correct.) 1818 Jan. 22. Schedule of deeds - transferred from O. Kane and wife to Harriet Hare. 1818 Feb. 9. Receipt to Oliver Kane for deeds in preceding schedule. 1814(?) May 4. Statement of Lydia Clark. (Case of Robt. Hare vs. Oliver Kane) accusing Mr. Kane and defending Mr. Hare. 1830 Aug. 31. Deposition of E. Bowen - his explanation of transactions between Mr. Hare and O. Kane.

Insurance on apparatus. 1825 Feb. 5. To Mr. Thos. Vose, from Robt. Hare. Sale of land and terms. 1825 Feb. 25. To Gen'l Cahoon, from Robt. Hare. Subject of money, last letter was open, and deed for Chapman. 1825 Feb. 27. To Mr. B. Bryant from Robt. Hare. Kane's refusal to exchange deeds on lands in Embden. Feb. 29. To Sarah, from Robt. Hare. Instructions on disposal of $200., and send Mr. Andrew Jones, S. Boston Glass Works $8... To "Dear Sir" - about advancing son money. March 1. To "My Dear Sir" - from Robt. Hare. In reference to money, abandoning studies and conduct. 1824 Sept. 7. To "My dear Aunt" - in reference to apparatus for duplicating letters. 1829? Poetry. To Gen'l Cahoon from Robt. Hare. In reference to check for $110. Contrivance for writing (must be as in foregoing letter to Aunt.)

did.unittitle: Letters. Clark and Robert Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1842 Mar. 6. To David H. Sumner, from Clark Hare. Statement of balance due Dr. Hare on Dalton Estate. 1842 May 23. To David H. Sumner, from Clark Hare. In reference to balance due Dr. Robt. Hare. June 6. To J.S. Littell, from Clark Hare. About editing Smith's leading cases. 1842 July 11. To Mr. Thompson, from Clark Hare. Property leased from Dr. Hare vacant and ready. 1842 Oct. 10. My dear ______, from Robt. Hare. will lend $75. 1842 Dec. 29. To John Merrick, from Robt. Hare. Accepts offer of Mr. Bryant for Embden portion of estate of Mrs. Hare's father, and conditions. 1842 Jan. 16. To Mr. H. Helmbold, from C. Hare. Mr. Kirk's rent in arrears, asking for payment. 1843 Apr. 1. To Mr. John Merrick, from Robt. Hare. Receipt of check for $500. for all real and personal property in town of Embden, Maine. 1843 June 15. "Sir", from C. Hare. In reference to money loaned by Dr. Hare. 1844 Dec. 16. Messrs. Hoopes and Lanning, from R.H. Hare. Request for payment of $140 to D.P. Brown. 1845 Feb. 19. To John Rutherford, from R.H. Hare. Money due Mr. Potts for building vault. 1845 March. Re: Chas. Potts vs. John Rutherford. Jan. 1. To W.G. Smith, from C. Hare. Acceptance of $125. by Mrs. Ames. 1845 Jan. 1 To Capt. Kartscher, from C. Hare. Enclosing copy of above note. June 24. To Geo. Emlen, from Clark Hare. Making appointment with Mr. Matthews for comparing bill. 1846 July 1. To Geo. Emlen, from Clark Hare. Again requesting meeting to compare bills with Mr. Dick and Mr. Matthews. 1846 Sept. 15. Case of Moore vs. Church. "Dear Sir" from R.H. Hare. 1862 Dec. 19. Loose paper - U.S. Sanitary Commission - meeting called of executive committee. 1846 Sept. 15. To Mrs. Ticknor, from Clark Hare. In reference to annuity. 1846 Sept. 19. To Mr. H. Zantzinger. Case of Moore vs. the Church. 1846 Sept. 19. To Geo. Campbell. Served in case of Moore vs. Church. 1846 Sept. 26. Served to Mr. Guillon in case of Howell vs. Bournonvill. 1846 Oct. 5. To Jas. Smith, from Robert Hare. Insurance on stable and tavern. 1846 Oct. 20. To J.R. Tyson, from Clark Hare. In reference to papers of Schuylkill Bank. 1846 Oct. 23. To Mr. John Gorman, from R.H. Hare. Informing to repair stable floor. 1846 Oct. 25. To Monsieur le Lt. G'l Baron Picquet, from Clark Hare. (In French) 1840 Nov. 9. To H.M. McIlvaine, from Clark Hare. Payment of one of Mr. Watson's bills by the Depestre family. 1846 Nov. 11. To C.P. Dexter, from Clark Hare. As executor of late Robt. Hare, needs information on Mr. Hare's accounts as trustee of Mr. Picquet in reference to sale of "flats". 1846 Nov. 11. To Edward Blake, from Clark Hare. Requesting information on sums collected on sale of "Flats" for Mr. Picquet by R. Hare. 1846. To Thos. Wharton, from Clark Hare. In reference to Moore vs. The Phila. Saving Fund Society. Dec. 14. To Mr. R.M. Lee, from Calrk Hare. Estate of Michael Butler, date of meeting for auditing accounts of Sevin Harmon, executor of Michael Butler, deceased. 1847 Jan. 2. To D. McLaughlin, from Clark Hare. Legal advice. 1847 Jan. 2. To D. McLaughlin, from Calrk Hare. Declining fee in case. 1847 Jan. 11. To Edmund Depestre, from Clark Hare. Steps being taken for Miss Depestre and Mrs. Robt. Hare under estates of Madame de Pausal and Madam St. Didier. Claim against Mr. Hare's estate. 1847 Jan. 16. To P.P.F. Degrand, from R.H. Hare. Sale of New Orleans bonds of 1836. 1847 Mar. 2. To Mr. H.G. Burrows, from Clark Hare. In regard to Miss Lyon's claim, Mr. Schifferstein, Baltimore is new administrator of estate of A.F. Picquet. To Col. John Hare Powel, from C. Hare. Obtained payment of money, and Mr. Binney will forward it, and will appropriate other $40. as instructed. 1847 June 29. To Col. Powel, from Horace Binney, Jr., Cehck for $210. enclosed, and request for signed authority. 1847 July 3. To Horace Binney, from Col. Powel. Received check and return "authority". 1847 July 14. To Dr. Hare, Newport, from Horace Binney, Jr. About rent on store at 133 S. 6th St. To Mr. Wharton, from C. Hare. In reference to Bill of Exception in case of Moore vs. The Saving Fund. 1847 Oct. 13. To Messrs. Greene & Co., from C. Hare. Remittance enclosed. Reference to iron castings and box of engravings. 1848 Jan. 20. To Joseph Shefferstein, from Clark Hare. Legal advice on receiving balance of Mr. Picquet's estate as new executor. 1848 Mar. 1. To H.T. Grant, from Clark Hare. Case of Newbould vs. Ridgeway. Request an assignment of errors. 1848 Mar. 10. To E.S. Miller, from Clark Hare. Receipt of check for Col. Powell for ground rent on lot on Ridge Rd. 1847 Mar. 16. To R.M. Lee, from C. hare. Request to know if defendant will settle judgement without recourse of execution. Mar. 27. To H.T. Grant, from Clark Hare. Case of Newbold vs. Ridgeway. Apr. 3. To J.O. Ewing, from Clark Hare. Advising of lien for taxes existing on property belonging to Mrs. Sergeant in neighborhood of Ridge Rd. May 10. To H.T. Grant, from C. Hare. "Newbold vs. Ridgeway". Case will be settled on receipt of $10. with costs. June 30. To Miss Ann C. Esling, from C. Hare. Request payment of mortgage of house on 5th St. to Mr. W. Esling. 1848 Sept. 4. To Horace Binney, H. Williams, Dr. Morton, from Clark Hare. About bequest of Mrs. E.P. Stott to Mrs. Minederogede of Williamsburg, Va. 1852. To Dr. Hare, from Samuel Webb. Plan for Hare St., division of lots, terms for ground rent, erection of houses and method of raising money to meet advance expenses. 1852 June 21. To Samuel Webb, from Clark Hare. Declined proposal of foregoing letter. Map-Hare Street in Philadelphia between Schuylkill River and Darby Road, 20.3 x 31.7 cm. 1853 Oct. 19. To Messrs. John Gendell, I. Badger and Charles Reed, from Clark Hare. Request for fulfillment of terms on property in West Philadelphia. 1855 June 18. To J.A. Gendell, from Clark Hare. In reference to contract and ground rent deed. 1856 Jan. 2. Haines (?) & Sons, from Clark Hare. "Washed his hands" (?) 1856 Mar. 25. To Frederick Prime (?), from Clark Hare. In order not to disturb father's mind, enclose draft for $5102. Mar. 31. To Mrs. Muller, from Mrs. Clark Hare. In reference to rooms, cannot go to Germantown. June 20. "Dear Sir", from Clark Hare. Renting of rooms. 1857 July 27. To Robert Ralston, from Clark Hare. Transaction on lots. May 25. To Rev. H.S. Howell, Delaware Water Gap, from Clark Hare. Renting of rooms for 8 weeks.

Notes and observations made abroad, mostly in England ans Scotland on politics, voting, people, buildings, streets, towns, riots, churches, army, mines, government, literature, labor, etc.

did.unittitle: Letterbook. Robert Hare.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1841 July. 2 letters in French. 1842 Oct. 31. Memo in reference to deed of Vermont lands. 1842 Oct. 1. To Jacob Wain - remittance to Ferdinand. 1842 Nov. 9. To John Merrick - acknowledged remittance and request to act as agent with Mr. Bryant. 1842 Oct. 8. To Geo. Emlen, Broad of trustees - glass of window in lecture room treated for privacy and cutting of tree branches. 1843 Jan. 21. To B. Silliman - remittance for printing and in reference to Journal articles and book on organic chemistry. 1843 Jan. 30. To Mr. Long - giving preference as tenant of Bull's Head. 1843 Feb. 9. To Mr. J.R. McGregor - about selling fixtures, furniture and other articles to succeeding tenant of Bull's Head. 1843 Feb. 25. To John Merrick - in reference to deed to property. 1843 Feb. 26. About incomplete copy of Turner's work and whether pamphlets are to be published, and request for new works on Chemistry, Electricity, Galvanism, and Electromagnatism. 1843 Mar. 22. To Edward Curtis - scientific investigation of vessels exposed to storm. 1843 Mar. 5. To Mr. J.P. Pollock - discontinuance of subscription. Mar. 23. Messrs. Tatem & Bros. - use of lead pipes with Schuylkill water, and analysis of Schuylkill and Croton waters. 1843 April 20. James Kirk - bad note. Messrs. Harnden & Co. - expenses on packets delivered to be charged to R. Hare. 1843 June 27. Wm. H. Russell - in reference to U.S. Stock under Nightingale estate and Galen Salt stock under Mr. Kane's estate. To Whom It May Concern - description of improvements made on Hydrostaric blowpipe. To the Commissioner of Patents of the United States - application for patent on improvements in the Hydro-oxygen blowpipe. 1843 June 26. Sworn statement as inventor of above improvements on blowpipe. 1843 June 28. Dr. Jones - had hoped for arrangements with Russian government for patent. Fraudulant use of blowpipe by employee. 1843 June 28. P. Simmonds - services in sending publications abroad. 1843 Sept. 16. D. Ames, Cashier of Bank of Middletown - in reference to 2 drafts to be held. 1843 Sept. 16. Dr. Jones, Washington, D.C. - in reference to specifications or claim on a particular metal. 1843 Sept. 20. Wm. H. Russell - document appointing administrator of will of John Innes Clark. 1843 Sept. 20. Memo about writing Chas. F. Chase in reference to lots in village of Somerset and to Mr. Hood in reply to offer for Mrs. Hare's property in Somerset. 1843 Sept. 22. D. Ames, Cashier of Bank of Middleton - order to pay $1351 to Prime & Shino, N.Y. 1843 Sept. 22. Messrs. Prime and Shino - collect draught for deposit and send $200. check. 1843 Sept. 24. H.L.B. Levy, N.Y. - in reference to Dr. Drake's experiments (making gas to work engine). 1843 Sept. 30. Memo having written Wm. P. Phala about renting Bull's Head. 1843 Sept. D.H. Sumner - about interest on bond. 1843 Oct. 4. Messrs. Carey & Lea - in response to Chemistry publication. 1843 Oct. Wm. H. Russell - termination of trust fund under Mrs. Clark's will. 1843 Oct. 12. Mr. James Torbert - offer of terms for Bull's Head Inn and allowing refund. 1843 Oct. 13. Messrs. Chamberlain - criticism of apparaturs received but will give it a try. Inquiry on electric machine with magnet. 1843 Oct. 14. Prof. Henry - request to know his theories that may be introduced when publishing treatises of galvanism and electro magnatism, and other scientific inquiries. 1843 Oct. 17. Prof. Millington - publications for term book at Wm. & Mary's College. 1843 Oct. 18. Prof. Henry - request to borrow science book. Memo - have written Mr. J. Miller to send scientific books. 1843 Oct. 30. Baring Bros. Co. - application for credit for son Robert who is traveling. 1843 Nov. 8. Mr. Prime - sending check. 1843 Nov. 13. In reference to books ordered and payment of same. 1843 Nov. 13. Mr. Matthews - dispossessment notice for tenement next to Bull's Head Inn. 1843 Nov. 13. Baring Bros. & Co. - in reference to credit for son traveling to Italy. 1843. Mr. Berzelius - (in French) 1843 Nov. 16. To Gentlemen on committee of the Medical Class of the University of Pennsylvania - in reply to request for copy of introductory address. 1843 Nov. 23. To James Ash - in reference to dispossession of tenement. 1843 Dec. 5. Mr. Ashe - in reference to rent of property to Mr. Kerns. 1843 Dec. 6. Mr. James Ash - rent of tenement and repairs. 1843 Dec. 8. Mr. James Ash - notice to vacate. To rent to Mr. Kerns. 1843 Dec. 8. Mr. Kerns - notice having paper drawn up to lease Inn and request about purchase of articles which Mr. Ash might want to sell. 1843 Dec. 13. Mr. Paine, Cashier of Union Bank, N.Y. - from Frederick Prime - New Orleans bonds. 1843 Dec. 16. Mr. James McGregor - notice to vacate Inn. Messrs. Chamberlain - return of merchandise and payment of balance due. 1843 Dec. 25. Mr. James Ash - notice of dispossession of tenement. 1843 Dec. 25. Mr. James Ash - (evidently copy of previous letter). 1843 Dec. 25. Messrs. Chas. & J.Watt - correction on essay publication. 1844 Jan. 4. Mr. J.R. Mcgregor - making appointment to see about rent due. 1844 Jan. 25. Joseph L. Ritter - in reply to queries on metals. 1844 Jan. 29. Sending pamphlets to be distributed in England and ordering chemistry books (think it was written to Mr. John Miller). 1844 Feb. 8. Mr. Kirk - regarding lease. 1844 Feb. 12. Mr. Geo. Marsh - on contents of ores of Platina and where it can be obtained. 1844 Feb. 26. Messrs. A.& D. Chamberlain - deliverance of articles (magnet and balance. 1844 Feb. 15. Mr. Francis Murkse, Sec. of the Nat'l Institute - acceptance to speak on causes of storm, especially tornadoes and hurricanes. 1844 Feb. 28. Mr. John Miller - payment on account and request for more publications. 1844 Jan. List of names sent to Mr. John Miller to which pamphlets were requested to be sent. 1844 Apr. 8. Messrs. Fitch & Co. - request to forward funds for son, George Harrison Hare. 1844 Apr. 9. Mr. J. Miller - order for publications and inquiry on forwarding letter to son Robert H. Hare, and number of copies printed of certain publications. 1844 May 1. William Wilkins - discussing igniting gunpowder and rock blasting by galvanism for U.S. Government harbour defenses as requested by House of Representatives. 1844 May 8. At liberty to use statement in regards to origin of process for exploding gun powder by galvanic circuit. 1844 May 21. Messrs. Capwell & Bros. - (presume it's description of scientific equipment ordered). 1844 June 27. Baring Bros. & Co. - in reference to account for use by son, R.H. Hare. 1844 June 28. Mr. Pennington - order for publications. 1844 July 6. Mr. Dobson - request for volumes of journal to complete set. 1844 Oct. 20. Messrs. Prime, Ward & King - request for bill of exchange on Baring Bros. 1844 Oct. 30. Messrs. Baring Bros. & Co. - sending bill of exchange to credit of account. 1844 Oct. 31. A. Stout, M.D., Easton, Pa., - accepting a pupil. 1844 Nov. 13. Mr. Whiteman - in reference to apparatus received. Part O.K., but Bell Glass broken. 1844 Nov. 23. Wm. H. Rupel - about Mrs. Kane's money, from estate of Clark and Nightingale. 1844 Nov. 23. Mr. J.M. Wightman - replacement of broken bell. 1844 Nov. 30. Mr Joseph M. Wightman - bell glass received and check enclosed. 1844 Nov. 23. Editors of the American Journal Science - correction of an error in strictures on Dove's law of storms. 1844 Dec. 8. "My dear friend" - in reference to article sent and whether it will be published in next number. Family news. Memo - sent check to Dan'l Davis, Boston for bill for apparatus and ordered earthenware jars. 1845 June 30. Mrs. Eliza Ward - sending check as loan. Memo - written ordering wire and publications. 1845 Mar. 10. "My dear sir" - settlement of Mr. Kane's account. 1845 Mar. 14. Dr. Froust - fused platina and furnishing text books. 1845 Mar. 23. "Dear sir" - correction and explanation on treatise. 1845 Apr. 24. Mr. Voight, Agent of the Glass Works - order for jars. 1845 May 6. Mr. James Forbet - sending dark bay horse and in payment make repairs on tenement. Mr. Auner - list of books being sent to be bound. 1845 May 22. Memo - sent check to G.P. Hutchinson and requested Mr. Pennington to procure Journals. Messrs. Johnson & Cooke - order for Platina foil. 1845 Dec. 31. Messrs. Baring Bros. & Co. - pay Johnson & cooke ten punds. Thos. Riddle and others, Members of a Committee of the American Phila. Society - declining to be subscriber to books. 1846 Feb. 11. Chas. B. Trigo - Restitution of charter of West Phila. Railroad Company - reasons for incompletion. 1846 May 22. Mr. Enos Kern - conditions on which Inn be conveyed on a permanent ground rent. 1846 May 25. To the celebrated G.J. Berzelius - explanation in reply to his displeasure over quotations of his published in American Journal of Science. 1846 May 25. "Dear sir" - rent on tavern. 1846 May 29. Memo - have written to Messrs. Johnson & Cooke, London - order for palladium. 1846 June 5. Mr. Pennington - order for publications. "Dear sir" - yield of sample of platina and cost. 1846 June 27. Mr. Enos Kerns - repairs on tenement. Wm. A. Clark, Cashier of Bank of R.I. - pay balance due to Miss Sarah Gibbs. 1846 Nov. 24. To the Editors of the Chemist (not sent) - about scientific pamphlets. 1847 Jan. 18. Dr. Farnum - regarding yield of platina and costs of converting it into sponge and the fusion. 1847 Jan. 27. Memo - requested Mr. Jas. Miller to receive and pay for order of platina wire and send scientific publications. 1846 Dec. 30. Messrs. Loomis & Peck - unable to give treatise on chemistry proper examination to warrant recommending to public. 1847 Oct. 27. "Dear sirs" - check enclosed, receipt requested. 1847 Dec. 13. James P. Hutchinson - in reference to bonds of Rogers brothers and mortgage on loan to them. 1847 Dec. 13. Mr. John Miller, bookseller, London - method of sending periodicals. 1848 Nov. 21. Edmund Burke, Commissioner of Patents - amended petition and description as required. 1848 Nov. 23. Edmund Burke, Commissioner of Patents - have sent specimens devised for manufacturing concentrated manure. 1848 Nov. 27. Professor Henry - about apparatus to be presented to Smithsonian Institute. 1849 Feb. 10. Charles Cumming & Co. - performing experiment. 1849 Mar. 1. Wm. H. Russell - estate of Lydia Clark and receipts to be signed. John Innes Kane - in reference to shares of Providence Bank stock due to grandchildren, heirs of Mr. Clark. 1849 Mar. 22. Wm. H. Russell - requesting receipts for money due Mrs. Kane's children. 1849 Nov. 8. Henry - Sale of volumes of Annuales de Chymie and delivering lectures in Washington and apparatus for ozone. 1849 Mar. 28. Wm. H. Russell - received receipts and enclose checks. 1849 Mar. 6. Memo - received receipt and sent last check due to Mr. Kane's children. 1849 May 22. Mr. G. Ogilose - regarding error in billing for books never purchased. 1850 Nov. 28. Mr. Charles Cumming - granting request to put invention into use without reservations. 1850 Nov. 20. "Dear Sir" - On the disposal of dead animals in New York City by converting to fertilizer. 1850 Nov. 29. Prof. Henry, Smithsonian Institute - a documentary to be filed to secure against unfair dealings or plagiarism, and complete description of the process of preventing putrefaction in organic substances and converting into manure. "My dear sir" - happy proposals are approved by the Mayor, and the chemistry of organic matter. 1850 Nov. 28. Mr. Charles Cumming - proposal and condition to grant permission to use certain inventions in business. Signed acceptance of said proposal. 1851 Oct. 21. Chas. B. Trego, Treas. of the American Philosophical Society, Enclosing letter tendering resignation if required to contribute. 1851 Dec. 28. Mr. Thos. Leonard - authorization to shift stairwell and extend dining room at the Bull's Head Inn at own expense. 1848 Dec. 15. Mr. H.M. Taylor - requesting accounting of money claimed due on lands in Ohio. "My dear Professor" - facts, obligations and conditions upon donations of apparatus to the Smithsonian Institute. The packing of apparatus without approval and desire to have those back which were meant to be kept. Professor Henry - in reference to donation of articles to Smithsonian. 1852 Mar. Mr. Wm. Forney - disagreement on printing bill and payment of same. Memo on patent for making starch. 1852 Mar. 29. "My dear Sarah" - Chesapeake & Delaware Loan Certificate. "Dear Sir" - in reference to Mrs. Harned and Mr. Browne's father's estate. 1853 June 7. Mr. J.R. Tyson - resignation as director of School of Design. 1855 Mar. 8. Postmaster, Madison, Wisconsin - inquiries as to whereabouts of Ferdinand Britton and J. Jefferson. 1855 May 2. Messrs. Nieurnsee and Nielson - payment of account with National Hotel. 1855 Dec. 3. Messrs. Partridge & Britton - list of expenses that should be paid out of balance of lectures and does not wish report of lecture to be used because of errors. 1855 Dec. 8. Messrs. Partridge & Britton - in reference to lecture report and spiritualism and "spiritscope". "Dear Sir" - putting apparatus in trust with Wagner Institute and the donation of an electrical plate. 1856 Feb. 12. About a Miss Allen's claim for $5. - something to do with a Spiritoscope. 1856 May 19. "My dear sir" - in reference to work on spiritualism. 1856 June 12. "My dear sir" - about the printing of copies of revised edition of Tabernacle address. 1856 June 25. To the Carrier of the Sun Newspaper - make collection and discontinue delivery. 1856 June 20. "Dear Sir" - (hard to understand) 1856 June 27. Mr. Barry - about selling pamphlets. 1856 June 27. Mr. Thos. D. Rotch - desirous to make satisfactory arrangement. 1856 Sept. 25. My dear M. - discussion on Christianity. 1856 Nov. 3. Mr. Thos. D. Rotch - in reference to company manufacturing Hare's fertilizer. 1856 Oct. 31. Loring Thayer - could not lecture on Spiritualism but sending pamphlets which contain the matter and the cost of each. To promote the cause of Spiritualism, an ad for "Spiritscopes". Mr. Thos. D. Rotch - honored by name Hare appearing in name of company manufacturing fertilizer, but unwilling to head an undertaking under such financial arrangements. 1856 Dec. 29. "My dear Professor" - about the book on the whirlwind theory to be presented before the Secretary of the Navy or Naval Committee of the Senate. 1857 Feb. 8. H. Steele - in reference to Spiritscope and "mediums". 1857 Feb. 8. Mr. O.L. Cockran - about delivery of "Spiritscope" ordered. 1857 Feb. 8. "Dear sir" - concerning his works on spiritualism and mediums. States he's personally acquainted with worthy spirits such as Franklin and Washington. 1857 Feb. 10. "Dear sir" - referring to a session with the "Spirits" wherein a murdered man was named and also his murderer. 1857 Feb. 18. Messrs. Partridge & Britton - in reference to expenses on publications on spiritualism. 1857 Feb. 12. I.H. McDonald - criticism on spiritualism articles and persons. The comparing of Spiritualism and Christianity. 1857 Apr. 30. Mr. Relaux - about medium, Mrs. Nabin and communications with the Nazarine. 1857 May 1. Mr. Maulding - concerning purchase of a "Spiritscope". 1857 May 1. Mr. Maulding - about "Spiritscope". 1857 June 4. F.I.B's criticism of his writings in Spiritual Telegraph. 1857 June 8. Dr. Gourley - inquiry as to whether he can obtain the works for the good of the cause (spiritualism). 1857 June 12. "Dear Sir" - unwilling to pay additional expense on books and concerning Dr. and Mrs. Gourley's adverse stand in relation to his having books. 1857 July 3. Professor Silliman - in reply to letter accusing opinion on "spiritualism" as ignorance, and request to publish letters. 1857 July 15. T.W. Dunbar Moodie - to acknowledge order for Spiritscope and discussing spirit friends and their feelings toward slavery, particularly Washington, Franklin and Calhoun. 1857 July 25. A.E. Newton - order for 10 copies of the "Spiritualist" and subscribing to the N.E. Telegraph and about articles published. Mr. Charles Partridge - complaining of criticism on articles published. 1857 Sept. 21. Francis Peters - answer to the question "How far is water compressible?", describing experiments made. 1857 Oct. 8. Professor Henry, Sec. of the Smithsonian Institute - notification that apparatus for fusing platina has been sent and description of the apparatus. Also that "Spiritscope" allowed him to know of presence of Prof. Henry's wife and daughter at Montreal. 1857 Oct. 8. "My dear sir" - delivering graduating apparatus of Tyler and explanations. Also "Spiritscope" signified lost brother as spirit. 1857 Oct. 8. Chas. Partridge - recompose copy as a sort of handbill. 1857 Nov. 3. Chas. Partridge - about his communications published and to be published in the "Spiritual Telegraph". 1857 Nov. 24. "Dear Sir" - concerning copies of the "Telegraph" and copies of essay. 1857 Nov. 26. In reference to communications made with Jesus from the Spirit World. 1857 Dec. 23. J.S. Crampton - opinions respecting the Bible and Spiritualism, and about publications. 1857 Dec. 25. Professor C. Avery - manifestations of spiritualism and references to publications. 1850 Nov. 21. Henry Young, President of the Manhattan Gas Co.,- on the subject of using the gas line so as to sell at a better price. Feb. 6. Repeating invitation to call. 1856 May 19. In reference to work on Spiritualism. 1846 June 29. Mr. Jacob Weisman - expected to receive large masses of plumbago in return for consultations, correspondence, etc. but instead received your rates. Portion of a loose letter - about platina and the sensation of heat in chlorine gas.

did.unittitle: Diary. Mrs. Tillinghast (Rebecca Willing's mother)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Review of the past (probably Mrs. Tillinghast, Rebecca Willing's mother). Loose pages - writings on Mother, Father, death, poetry, riddles and jokes). Pg. 12 - married first to Chas. J. Air. Pg. 14 - portrait Pg. 15 - fire and sister's death. Pg. 16 - Mr. Air killed by highwayman. Pg. 19-21 - family (geneology, characters, etc.) Pg. 22-24 - Father's character and deeds. Pg. 28-29 - Harriet Clark Hare. Pg. 30-31 - Extracts from "Stories of Venice" and other literature, and thoughts on art. Pg. 48 - Spiritual subjects, etc. Pg. 49-59 - Traits of characters ( Sir Wlater Scott, Washington, Webster, etc.) Pg. 60-69 - Central and South American affairs. Pg. 71-77 - Effects of the abolishment of slavery. Pg. 78-94 - Daniel Webster. Pg. 96 - Poems by daughter Rebecca. Pg. 114 - Ozone Pg. 121 - Narcotics Pg. 135 - Architecture Pg. 150 - Religious references Pg. 175 - History - British India Pg. 212 - Trees Pg. 224 - Foreign countries Pg. 249 - The Soul, Uses of the Mind Pg. 272 - Poetry Pg. 300 - Education Pg. 314 - Comets, Planets, etc. Pg. 320 - Atlantic telegraph cable Book reviews, biographies, quotations and religious subjects throughout.

Then confined to home for the birth of Truxton while Dr. Hare sails to the Mediterranean and back, and then to Havana to meet her husband. Also a newspaper article The Tammany of Naples, and instructions for knitted shirt.

did.unittitle: E.P. Hare - Notes on events in Europe, Washington, Charleston, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sept. 12, 1896 - E.P. Hare - on leaving Geneva for Paris. August 1897 - Harford - dinner on the lawn. Dec. 1897 - Reflections on life, anxiety about Truxton playing football. May 1898 - Washington. May 22, 1898 - Dinner in Washington. Speaker Reed and opinion on War with Spain over Cuba. Music. Escorted by General Miles, head of the army. Opinions of books. May 23 - Talk about Queen of Spain. Aug. 20, 1898 - Bar Harbor. Jan. 1906 - Katy's death and funeral. Jan. 29 - Charleston. Dances. Feb. 2 - Visit to Drayton Magnolia Gardens. Feb. 4 - Meeting new found cousin. Comments on butler at boardinghouse. Back to Phila.

scopecontent.p: Detailed journal of fishing and hunting trip. By train from Philadelphia to Toronto ans westward through Canada to Vancouver, then up to northern British Columbia ( Telegraph Creek). Sheep and goat hunting, then moose and caribou hunting. (From handwriting, possibly Horace B. Hare)

did.unittitle: Robert Hare. Material relating to Estate of John I. Clark.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 1813 Oct. 30. To Robert Hare from Oliver Kane, Providence - About lands belonging to Mr. Clark's estate. 1819 August. Vermont documents. 1820 Sept. 11. To Oliver Kane from Francis B. Fogg - relative to bill filed against estate on Tennessee lands obtained for services during Revolutionary War by Gen. Thomas Clark. 1820 Oct. 27. To Robert Hare fro Oliver Kane, Albany - instructions on sending answers to bill against estate on Tennessee lands. 1822 Mar. 11. Francis B. Fogg from Oliver B. Kane - in reference to executors, heirs and Tennessee lands of estate of J.I. Clark. 1821 Dec. 12. Substance of letter to Oliver Kane from Francis Fogg, telling of bill of equity filed against heirs by heirs of Thomas Mitchell. Account of lots sold for notes due in Embden divided between Kane and Hare. 1822 Sept. 28. Division of lots in Embden, maine, letters and papers concerning same on pages 41 to 46. Documents relating to lands in Fayette, Chenango, New York, pages 47 to 49, and a note on Mr. Cooper and his novel "The Spy". 1820 May 13. Documents relating to Ohio Lands - pages 55 to 57. Documents relating to lands in maine - pages 63 to 82. Documants relating to Dalton property - pages 83 to 101. Documents relating to Vermont property - pages 102 to 108. Tennessee property - pages 109 to 119. 1818. Papers relating to settlement between J. Whipple and O. Kane - pages 121 to 143. 1821 Sept. 15. Copy of account rendered to R. Hare by John Whipple - pages 114 to 147. Copy of Deed of Land in Providence, R.I. - pages 148 and 149. Relating to Embden property - page 151. List of personal property in house of J. whipple in trust for Mrs. Lydia Clark - page 152. Relating to account of R. Hare with Prime, Eard and Sands, pages 154 and 155. Robert Hare and Oliver Kane's account with Oliver Kane - pages 155 to 163. 1822 May. Letter to R. Hare from O. Kane - about an exchange of lands - pages 164 to 165. Oliver Kane in account with Robert Hare - pages 166 to 175. 1824. Letters relating to Jersey Field lots - pages 176 and 177. Mrs. Clark's Legacy Fund Account - pages 178 to 181. Copy of Mr. Clark's Will - page 182. Transfer of shares in Exchange Bank to Lydia Clark by John Whipple - page 185. Deposit by R. Hare for O. Kane in Providence Bank of dividends on stock - page 185. Relating to Galen Salt Co. and Martin's Mortgage - page 186. Relating to Washington, D.C. property - pages 187 to 190. 1824. In reference to property near New Market Square, Phila.- pages 197 and 198. 1823-1824. Property on or near the Mohawk in New York - pages 210 to 213 and page 215. 1824 Oct. 7. Rhode Island Property - page 214. Notes on the settlement of Mr. Clark's Estate.

did.unittitle: Minutes of Common Council. City of Philadelphia. Robert Hare

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: R. Hare, Jr. (Clerk of Common Council, City of Philadelphia) List of the Standing and Joint Committees of Councils for 1832. 1832 Oct. 12. Minutes and results of election of Common Council. 1832 Oct. 16. Minutes and election of Mayor ( John Swift) of the city. 1832 Oct. 25. Minutes relative to gas lighting for city, encroachments in the River Schuylkill, appointment of members to take charge of various city squares, improvement of Girard lands, continuance of railroad along Broad St., and lowering of Chestnut and adjoining streets. 1832 Nov. 5. Minutes - election of inspectors of the Prison. 1832 Nov. 8. Minutes - passed ordinance fixing the regulation of Matlock St., resolution rendering thanks for physicians attendance in the Cholera hospitals, improving Chestnut St. landing (take down old Engine House and use materials in new fire houses), printing of copies of ordinances of the city and rules for the government of each council with a statement of property and its condition owned by the city, since the "Sisters of Charity" declined acceptance of the plate to be presented them for devoted exertions during the Cholera, money to be given to three institutions over which they preside, the Trusts, resetting of curb stone a public charge. Girard College plans, making water rents a lien on ral estate instead of detaching pipes if not paid, Rittenhouse Square, and about property of city bequeathed by Stephen Girard. 1832 Nov. 16. Meeting to memorialize Charles Carroll and other signers of the Declaration of Independence. 1832 Nov. 22. Minutes - Communication from City Treasurer presented account of Girard Fund, one from Board of Bldg. Commissioners informing of a vacancy on Board, from City Commission submitting schedule of all city properties exclusive of Girard estate, and from Auditors of Girard Fund. Resolution passed to expediate lighting city by gas, street paving, election of A.L. Pennock to Board of Building Commissioners for erecting suitable buildings for the accommodation of the Poor, on compensation of treasurer of Girard Fund Estate, Columbia railroad. 1832 Dec. 11. To elect six directors of the Poor Tax.
